urn:contentItem:4P0N-K060-TXN5-S3D7-00000-00CAMPUS CHATTER2006-10-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisEDUCATIONPg. 10CAMPUS CHATTERLISA MITCHELL

NURTURING DIGITAL NATIVES

"Digital natives", who roam the streets and commuter corridors sharing videos via mobile phone and blogging and Googling their way through the day, need a new "habitat" that meets their need for action and answers on demand - and the Queensland University of Technology plans to design it. Graham Keys, of the faculty of information technology, says it's time to redesign social and study spaces to enable the online generation to enjoy interactive learning with instant access to their preferred resources. Kiss the study corral bye-bye . . .

FORECASTING THE BURNING BUSH

With climate change confirming a hell's oven summer ahead, a La Trobe University innovation on firefighting software may prove a watershed for containing bushfires. Designed by senior software-engineering students, the Geographic Information Systems Import Tool imports landscape elevation data into a 12-year-old, forest firefighting simulator (elevation data has a dramatic effect on the rate a forest fire spreads). Until now, most of that process has been done manually. Applause please.

DOPE FIENDS DON'T DO IT BETTER

It's official: dope-head drunks don't drive better. A three-year study by Swinburne University of Technology in conjunction with Victoria Police shows that the effects of taking marijuana alone, or in combination with legal levels of alcohol, are deleterious to driving and, potentially, public safety. Participants under the influence who underwent a driving test using a simulator were offenders of "lane-weaving" and close encounters with other vehicles. The results showed that tests used by police to detect drivers under the influence are on the mark.

SCHOLARSHIP DRIVES

Only "bright" postgraduates need apply for a fistful of the $20 million scholarship booty on offer at the University of Melbourne. Candidates can pitch their best research ideas to the faculties of science, medicine, engineering, arts, education, architecture, law and commerce to win the living allowance, which frees them to pursue new frontiers of knowledge. Over at La Trobe University, $400,000 is available in scholarships and support programs to secure civil engineering students for 2007. La Trobe's drive, organised in partnership with industry, aims to overcome a shortage in the profession. The scholarships, worth $40,000 each over four years, are for the Bendigo campus.

Send your campus appointments, research, student, public seminars and course news to lisamitch@ozemail.com.au

urn:contentItem:7V3F-SV90-YB64-41ND-00000-00Sunday, March 1 - Pay TV2009-02-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisGREEN GUIDEPg. 38Sunday, March 1 - Pay TVbrad newsome

Entourage (series final)

Arena, 8.30pm

IT'S been a long time coming, but it looks as though Vince (Adrian Grenier) is finally headed for a serious meltdown. Having failed to capitalise on his success in the blockbuster Aquaman, he's sliding towards Hollywood untouchability and financial ruin. For the most part he's been able to maintain his strange serenity, but now crazy German director Verner Vollstedt (a wonderful Stellan Skarsgard) is heaping hay bales on the camel's back.

The big-budget forest-fire epic Smoke Jumpers might be Vince's last hope of making it back on to the A-list, but Vollstedt is making his life a misery, giving his best lines to other actors and forcing him to re-shoot one scene 50 times. E (Kevin Connolly) and Ari (Jeremy Piven) launch yet another rescue mission, but things don't look good. At least Turtle (Jerry Ferrara) seems to be having some luck - Jamie-Lynn Sigler (Meadow from The Sopranos) is back in town and wants to catch up. This season has been an absolute ripper, with inventive storylines, pages of great dialogue for Ari and Lloyd (Rex Lee), and laugh-out-loud moments by the dozen. The cast and the many guest stars seem to have had a ball. Although there's been an air of impending doom this season, there's also been a sense of security in the undying unconditional love between the main players (yes, even Ari). Entourage is all about friendship, which sort of makes it the male Sex and the City. For all their bluster and bravado, the boys' Care Bear moments are as touching and tender as anything involving Carrie & Co. For some reason I also get the warm-and-fuzzies thinking about how Ferrara and Sigler are now an item in real life. Perhaps I'm just a bit hormonal this week. Season six begins shooting in the States this month.

Evolutions: Bear Necessities

National Geographic, 8.30pm

A CORNY title, but a brilliant episode about the evolution of bears into species as different as the polar bear, the panda and the ant-eating sloth bear. Much of this radiation was the result of climate change, and it looks as though it might be happening again: the loss of Arctic ice seems to be increasing interbreeding between polar bears and grizzlies.

Lifestyle Food, 7pm

Worth a look

The Shield (W, 10pm).

Brilliant bad-cop drama.

Inside the Actors Studio (Bio, 9.30pm).

Monty Python's Flying Circus (Comedy, 7.30pm).

urn:contentItem:5F0C-VC61-F0JP-W460-00000-00Dunalley's scars run deep, two years on2015-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 54Dunalley's scars run deep, two years onBRUCE MOUNSTER and NICK CLARK

FROM the outside, everything appears to be normal again.

But for the Griffiths family, who lost their Dunalley home in the January 2013 bushfires, things will never be the same.

Scott Griffiths told the Sunday Tasmanian the family's new house was starting to look the part, the kids were doing well at work and at school, and his wife Deborah had found a good job.

However, he said the emotional scars from their bushfire ordeal - two years ago today - continued to run deep.

For many years he had worked as a postman in suburban Hobart and he'd always had well-paying jobs, but not since the fire.

And the memory of fleeing by car as a terrifying black, red and purple wall of fire rolled into view - then returning to the smouldering ruin that had been his home - still makes him emotional.

"The other day there was a little fire at Copping. It was really weird, the smell of the burning eucalypt - it just brought everything back," he said.

Mr Griffiths said there were some positives as well - some things that the family could be proud of.

"We are more loving and more caring, I suppose. A bit tighter," he said. Mr Griffiths, a former amateur boxer has opened a boxing gym in a shed at the front of his property. It already has 70 local members.

And at this year's Australian Amateur Boxing League titles in Hobart one of his charges won a silver medal, and another took bronze.

"That's going really well, that's keeping me driven and confident," he said. "It's about giving something back to the community." Mr Griffiths has also started fitness classes for people of all ages, which has the makings of a business venture.

He said by using his insurance payout to buy a modest kit home and doing a lot of the work himself he had also succeeded in wiping out the family's mortgage - a significant load off their mind.

"I never wanted to live in a big mansion," he said.

"The garden is starting to grow. The place is feeling more like our home, not a hotel," he said.

Fire conditions were rated catastrophic on January 4, 2013, when a firestorm tore through Dunalley and the South East, and Lake Repulse in the Derwent Valley, and an area south of Bicheno.

While the Forest Fire Danger Index was lower than in 1967, when 62 people died in the Hobart bushfires, there were a couple of factors that were worse. The temperature in Hobart, of 41.8C, was 2.8 degrees higher than 1967, and in 2013 the winds blew strongly from noon to 7pm compared with just an hour in 1967.

The 2013 fire started at Forcett and flared up on January 3. By the morning of January 4 it covered 1000ha with a perimeter of 20km.

The fire reached Dunalley about 3.25pm with embers causing spot fires throughout the town.

It jumped the canal and continued down the Tasman Peninsula to Murdunna. By the time it was contained and the smoke had cleared, 193 dwellings and 186 other buildings were destroyed including the Dunalley school and police station.

Up to 4000 people were forced to take shelter at Nubeena.

Despite fears that a loss of life looked inevitable, remarkably no one died, but the scale of the damage was shocking.

Dunalley resident Jim Baptist told how the red cedar structure that had been his home for six years had been destroyed in the January 4 blaze.

But he was relieved to save his cars, and the house rebuild had been quick - less than nine months - and had gone "incredibly smoothly".

"I've lost all of my photos, memorabilia and everything. I still go to pick something up then realise, 'Oh that's gone, burnt," he said.

"But I'm not fretting. I can manage without all of those things when it comes down to it." Mr Baptist said having a say in the layout of the new home meant he felt a greater affinity with this house.

"When it was first finished it was like a desert, really. I've really enjoyed getting the garden going," he said.

"Building the front fence. It was a great way to meet and get to know a few more people." Nearly $9 million raised in the Red Cross Bushfire Appeal has been distributed in the two years since the blaze.

Chair of the Red Cross Distribution Committee Pat Leary said about $330,000 remained.

"We are not going to distribute it just for the sake of it but will wait for a something worthwhile to develop," she said.The funds were distributed in Sorell, Tasman and Central Highlands council areas.

urn:contentItem:6F7D-FNN3-RT4W-B2PG-00000-00GHOST FOREST PINES AWAY1995-03-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisPg. 18GHOST FOREST PINES AWAYMCRAE T

KEYWORD-HIT Ghost forest pines away THE once attractive Beerburrum State Forest today contains the biggest log-storage facility in Australia and looks like a war zone. Work on the $1.5 million 40ha storage compound began at midday on November 7. That was the day after the second biggest plantation fire in Australia's history ran out of land to ravage when it reached the shores of Bribie Island, taking 4700ha of exotic pine with it. The operation began quickly to beat fungus and borer. Fire salvage task force manager Matthew Grant said the compound now housed 315,000 tonnes of salvaged logs, continually sprinkled by creek water. ""By the time the operation is complete and there are 400,000 tonnes of logs stacked in here, if you laid them end to end, they'd go to Perth and back,'' Mr Grant said. Two hundred employees, including some who had worked on a similar salvage operation after the Ash Wednesday fires in South Australia, have been operating around the clock, at 10 times the normal work rate for three months. ""It's a $10 million operation worth $40 million in revenue from salvaged logs to the government and around $400 million more to the industry. THE fallen forest . . . Beerburrum State Forest fire salvage task force manager Matthew Grant expects to supply mills for five years.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Vic: North-east fires expected to spread tomorrow</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Susan Murdoch</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>MELBOURNE, Jan 19</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Firefighters in Victoria's north-east are bracing for another day of extreme conditions with a total fire ban declared statewide for tomorrow.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Strong winds continue to fan blazes which have now swept across more than 65,000 hectares of bushland.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Department of Sustainability and Environment spokesman Mike Leonard said fires around Mt Bogong, Mt Feathertop, Mountain Creek, Bald Hill and Razorback merged overnight.</p><p>Another fire, in the Pinnabar area south of Corryong, had linked up with blazes burning across the border in the Kosciuszko National Park.</p><p>Mr Leonard said firefighters were preparing for worsening conditions, with forecasters expecting strong westerly winds and temperatures in the high 30s tomorrow.</p><p>But Mr Leonard said he was confident property owners would be ready if fires threatened private land.</p><p>"We've had 10 days to get ready for this," he said.</p><p>"Landowners have been making sure their houses are sealed up, fire breaks along their fences are in check, and their pumps work."</p><p>Work is also continuing to protect alpine resorts at Hotham, Mount Buffalo, Dinner Plains and Falls Creek.</p><p>"They've managed to withstand three difficult days and we're hoping that will continue to be the case," he said.</p><p>A group of 13 New Zealand firefighters with specialist forest fire knowledge arrived today to help relieve exhausted fire crews, who will enter their 13th day of battling the blazes tomorrow.</p><p>"They'll assist us with their skills, providing some expertise and fresh energy to help us up there," Mr Leonard said.</p><p>Discussions were also continuing with the army, with 70 to 80 defence personnel expected to be available by Tuesday to help fight the fires.</p><p>Country Fire Authority deputy chief officer Craig Lapsley said more than 50 community briefings had been held during the past few weeks to prepare residents for the threat.</p><p>"We're ensuring people in the area are well prepared and kept up to date with conditions," Mr Leonard said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:5F0H-1FR1-JCM0-63HB-00000-00Ebola crisis: Experts warn against complacency in fight to contain worst outbreak in history2015-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisEbola crisis: Experts warn against complacency in fight to contain worst outbreak in historyBy Africa correspondent Martin Cuddihy

It has been one of the biggest stories of 2014 and it does not look like it is going anywhere.

The Ebola crisis in West Africa has killed thousands of people and it will continue to do so in 2015.

Given the Ebola story has been a constant on the news for the best part of a year, some of the interest has gone. But ignoring the disease is fraught with danger.

On a US talk show recently, White House Ebola response coordinator Ron Klain warned the world against complacency.

"I think we're nearing a pivot point in this, where the number of new cases overall in West Africa has somewhat stabilized," he said.

"But this won't be done until we get all the way to zero. It's like a forest fire: a few embers burning, and the thing can reignite at any time."

A stark warning for an indiscriminate killer.

Scientists now believe the first Ebola victim was a two-year-old boy who caught the disease after playing either in or near a tree that housed a colony of bats.

From there he passed the virus onto his family and then to health workers in Guinea.

They then passed it onto their own families and thus the cycle began.

Ebola spread rapidly from country to country

What helped this become the worst ever outbreak of the disease was the fact the haemorrhagic virus was not identified as Ebola until late in March.

This gave it time to get embedded in the population - dense, hygiene poor rural parts of both Guinea and Liberia. From there it spread to Sierra Leone.

Initially the global response was subdued. Ebola was not a new story.

After all, there have been a few major international stories this year: Syria, Ukraine, and various disasters involving planes.

The deputy director of the US Centers for Disease Control in Kenya, Dr Joel Montgomery, has been to West Africa a few times this year.

Dr Montgomery helped to establish new offices in the three hardest hit countries.

When the outbreak was at its worst, in late August and early September, he was there.

"When I arrived it was just a complete and utter disaster. It was very much like a nightmare," he said.

"Seeing people actually die in the streets from Ebola. It was actually very devastating and very difficult to witness."

He paints a grim picture and has repeated the warning of Mr Klain about not becoming complacent.

Most experts believe it will be months, at the very least, before transmissions drop to such a point that the worry can dissipate.

Dr Gavin Macgregor-Skinner, an expert in public health and emergency medicine who has also spent time in West Africa this year, says the global response has failed the region.

"We're not dealing with this as an ongoing public health emergency. And that's been a huge failure."

Cultural practices and superstition key to Ebola spread: medic

It is a multifaceted problem. Compounding issues of poor infrastructure and the slow response by the international community are local superstitions, traditions and a lack of access to basic health services.

A lot of communities hold superstitions in regard to the Ebola detection teams.

People do not realise that soap and water are the best defence, and they sometimes seek help from religion and traditional healers before seeing a doctor.

Liberia's chief medical officer Dr Bernice T. Dahn said cultural practises would have to change to beat the virus.

"For the cultural practices, it's not a matter of banning it, it's a matter of behaviour change, behaviour change communication," Dr Dahn said.

"If you ban it, it could go underground and it could make things worse. So it's a matter of educating people, people understanding why things should be done right and not be done the wrong way, and they'll change behaviour."

Changing these cultural practices will take time and that means the disease keeps re-emerging in areas that have been declared Ebola free.

"We're seeing the virus circulate between the three countries. So where one area had beaten Ebola they're now getting new cases in," said Dr McGregor-Skinner.

"Until we change our intervention, until we change our strategy, until we use all the tools in the toolbox, we are going to keep seeing ... this Ebola virus circle amongst the three countries and we're going to keep seeing cases pop up."

Until that stops, the Ebola crisis will continue and you might be reading an iteration of this article this time next year.

urn:contentItem:4RJ3-FHX0-TWT8-Y0X5-00000-00NSW: Modern cars are fire traps, CSIRO research finds2008-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSNSW: Modern cars are fire traps, CSIRO research findsIlya GridneffSYDNEY Jan 8

  Modern car design makes for safer, more comfortable motoring, but for someone caught in a bushfire the latest models can be death traps.
   Research initiated by the NSW Rural Fire Service and conducted by Bushfire Cooperative Research Centre (BCRC) with CSIRO scientists has found new sedans are far more dangerous in fires than their heavy metal predecessors.
   The Australasian Fire Authorities Council (AFAC), the peak body for the fire and emergency services, has used the research to inform drivers what to do if caught in a bushfires.
   While, obviously, it's best to steer clear of fire-affected areas, if trapped, the AFAC instructs drivers to remain in their car.
   "Research shows you should park in an open area, turn off the engine and air-conditioning and get as low to the ground as possible," AFAC chief executive officer Naomi Brown told AAP.
   "They (cars) can be a fire trap but there are some things that can be done in this worst case scenario."
   Ms Brown advised all motorists to carry a woollen blanket that can be used to cover passengers.
   "New car designs have made a bad situation worse," she said.
   "Today's cars are more dangerous because there is much more plastic and glass," she said.
   "The plastic goes (burns) very quickly and the glass, too.
   "Before, car door handles, bumper bars and other parts were metal - the change in design has made it more dangerous."
   The study, conducted in January 2007 at the NSW Rural Fire Service Hot Fire Training Facility in Mogo, on the NSW south coast, used seven two-wheel-drive sedans, ranging in size, age and make.
   Lead researcher Justin Leonard, from the CSIRO's Sustainable Ecosystems, described the testing as "unique", saying the last similar tests were in the 1960s.
   In the simulated test, temperatures inside the cars surged to around 300 degrees.
   "Sheltering below the window line is the best strategy as the heat passes through the windows," Mr Leonard said.
   "Being underneath a woollen blanket down low keeps temperatures around 40 to 50 degrees and the blanket is also difficult to ignite," he said.
   Mr Leonard said smoke and toxic gases from melting components inside cars were often more significant than the heat.
   "People trapped in a car during an intense forest fire could expect the ordeal to last 15 minutes," he said.
   "But people need to become knowledgeable about bushfires, come to understand the situation and make the right decisions beforehand so they don't end up trapped."

urn:contentItem:7V2V-1J20-YBDY-R291-00000-00Towns on flee alert Get ready to leave, fire chiefs warn2009-02-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Towns on flee alert Get ready to leave, fire chiefs warnGeorgie Pilcher

WEATHER WOES

COMMUNITIES near Melbourne have been issued fresh bushfire warnings and told to prepare to flee, as more hot wind is forecast.

Fire authorities said severe fire weather was predicted for today and people in the Warburton/Yarra Valley area and near Enoch Point should be prepared.

Country Fire Authority State Duty Officer Neil Bumpstead said people wishing to leave should go this morning.

``We cannot stress enough that with limited road access in the Warburton Valley, traffic may become congested,'' Mr Bumpstead said.

``Being on the roads is dangerous during a fire threat.

Fire authorities have warned of extreme forest fire danger in the Mallee and very high fire danger across the state ahead of temperatures in the high 30s today and later this week.

The weather bureau says there is little chance of rain until Friday afternoon when thunderstorms are predicted for western Victoria.

Today is expected to reach 34C in Melbourne and up to 37C in Mildura with northeast to northwesterly winds averaging up to 25km/h.

A southwest wind change is expected in the fire areas around 3pm.

Several fires are still burning across the state and authorities are warning people to remain on alert. Today has been declared a total fire ban day for Victoria's northeast, northwest, eastern and central districts

Department of Sustainability and Environment spokesman James Todd said 3500 DSE crews, including international and interstate firefighters, and 600 CFA crews continue to fight fires in the Kilmore-Murrindindi complex, Wilson's Promontory and Bunyip State Park.

He said residents in the Warburton Valley and Yarra Valley areas should activate their fire plans ahead of the expected northerly winds and high temperatures, with areas between Warburton and Reefton most at risk.

``There are still fires burning to the north of Warburton and we have been working hard to protect the Warburton Valley, but given the weather conditions it poses some significant risks to the area,'' Mr Todd said.

``Given the dry conditions and no rain forecast for the rest of the week, it will be a concern for a while yet.

``If residents are making the decision to leave they should leave early. There will be a lot of vehicles and smoke on the road, which will make driving hazardous.''

Mr Todd said four major bushfires continued to burn out of control, the Kilmore-Murrindindi Complex North, and the Kilmore-Murrindindi Complex South, the Bunyip Ridge fire and one at Wilson's Promontory.

Terry Ryan from the weather bureau said Melbourne could expect a top temperature of 34C, but other parts of the state would reach 40C.

urn:contentItem:4RJ5-88M0-TX5J-V0W4-00000-00Modern car a plastic coffin in bushfires2008-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 16Modern car a plastic coffin in bushfiresIlya Gridneff

MODERN car design makes for safer, more comfortable motoring but for someone caught in a bushfire the latest models can be death traps.

Research for the NSW Rural Fire Service by Bushfire Co-operative Research Centre has found new sedans are far more dangerous in fires than their heavy metal predecessors.

The Australasian Fire Authorities Council, the peak body for the fire and emergency services, has used the research to inform drivers what to do if caught in a bushfire.

While, obviously, it's best to steer clear of fire-affected areas, if trapped, the council advises drivers to remain in their car.

"Research shows you should park in an open area, turn off the engine and air-conditioning and get as low to the ground as possible,'' AFAC chief executive officer Naomi Brown said.

"They (cars) can be a fire trap but there are some things that can be done in this worst-case scenario.''

Ms Brown advised all motorists to carry a woollen blanket that can be used to cover passengers.

``Today's cars are more dangerous because there is much more plastic and glass. The plastic goes (burns) very quickly and the glass, too. Before, car door handles, bumper bars and other parts were metal -- the change in design has made it more dangerous.''

The study, conducted in January 2007 at the NSW service's hot fire training facility in Mogo, on the NSW south coast, used seven two-wheel-drive sedans, ranging in size, age and make.

Lead researcher Justin Leonard, from the CSIRO's Sustainable Ecosystems, described the testing as ``unique'', saying the last similar tests were in the 1960s.

In the simulated test, temperatures inside the cars surged to about 300C.

"Sheltering below the window line is the best strategy, as the heat passes through the windows,'' Mr Leonard said.

"Being underneath a woollen blanket down low keeps temperatures around 40C to 50C and the blanket is also difficult to ignite,'' he said.

Mr Leonard said smoke and toxic gases from melting components inside cars were often more significant than the heat.

"People trapped in a car during an intense forest fire could expect the ordeal to last 15 minutes,'' he said.

"But people need to become knowledgeable about bushfires, come to understand the situation and make the right decisions beforehand so they don't end up trapped.''

urn:contentItem:47PH-8JF0-015H-N1K8-00000-00<published>2003-01-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Campers forced to flee from Bribie bushfires</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BRIBIE Island police asked some campers to move out of the national park camping grounds earlier this week due to a forest fire.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Sergeant David Crawford-Raby said he was working at Pebble Beach when he looked up and saw the red glow of fire on the Beerwah end of the island on Tuesday afternoon at 1.30pm.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> He was requested by the fire brigade to talk to the people camping.</p><p>"We are not sure how the fire started, we are conducting inquiries," he said.</p><p> "At this stage there is nothing suspicious."</p><p>  *  SERGEANT Crawford-Raby and Senior Sergeant Trevor Crawford of Deception Bay Police said they were unaware of any boat ramp rage in the area.</p><p> The Boating Industry Association of Queensland blames a shortage of boating facilities, caused by a lack of funding by the State Government and local authorities, for boat ramp rage that has erupted on the Queensland waterfront, with fists and abuse flying amongst the boating fraternity as they queue for long periods to use boat launching and retrieval facilities.</p><p> BIAQ general manager, Barry Hibberd said he had reports from across the state of problems caused by a shortage of boating facilities.</p><p> "Ramp rage is rife. It's like bushfire season on the water, with tempers simmering and flaring, resulting in abuse and in some cases fisticuffs," he said.</p><p> Mr Hibberd said relief could be in sight with a State Government review of the state's boat registration levy.</p><p> Primary Industries Department Minister, Henry Palasczczuk recently announced a review of the distribution of the $2 million raised each year by the levy, which is used to fund recreational fishing activities.</p><p> Mr Hibberd it was a bone of contention with boat owners that they paid the levy but got nothing for it.</p><p> "We've been lobbying State Government for a number of years now to improve the infrastructure and facilities, such as boat ramp areas, because there are more than 170,000 registered power boats in this state.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4VFY-KGC0-TXX1-F1KX-00000-00Winds pummel Europe At least 15 dead in storm2009-01-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 18Winds pummel Europe At least 15 dead in stormBarcelona

HURRICANE-FORCE winds have lashed Spain and France, killing at least 15 people including four children when part of a sports hall collapsed, while more than a million were left without power.

High winds, gusting up to 150km/h in northern Spain, brought down part of a sports hall in Sant Boi de Llobregat, near Barcelona, killing the children and injuring nine.

Spanish media reported the children had been playing baseball outside but took shelter in the building.

``It seems that the roof shifted and brought down part of the wall,'' a regional government spokeswoman said.

Meanwhile, French forecasters warned the storms could be as ferocious as the tempest in 1999, which uprooted millions of trees, although over a more limited geographical area.

They reported record-breaking winds, reaching 184km/h at Perpignan.

The winds caused widespread disruption in both countries, with 1.3 million homes experiencing power cuts in France and tens of thousands in Spain also without power as high voltage lines were brought down.

The weather also wreaked havoc on the roads, with fallen trees hampering engineers struggling to restore power.

Apart from the children in the hall, a 52-year-old woman died in Barcelona when a collapsed wall crushed her.

Another woman died in the northern Castilla-Leone region when a door, lifted by the winds, crashed into her.

In Galicia, in northwestern Spain, a civil guard sergeant was killed by a falling tree as he was directing traffic.

In the southeastern Spanish province of Alicante, a 51-year-old man was also killed by a collapsing wall, while one of six seamen rescued from their Portuguese cargo ship by helicopter off Galicia died.

The death toll also included a municipal employee near Barcelona and a 60-year-old man in Spain's Catalonia province.

Four people died in southwestern France, including two drivers who were killed by falling trees.

A 78-year-old also died when he was hit by flying debris outside his home.

Meanwhile, a 73-year-old woman died in the southwestern Gironde department when the storm cut electricity powering her breathing machine.

In Spain's northern Basque country, waves as high as 21.5m were recorded off Cape Matxitxako, according to a spokesman for the regional interior ministry.

Some 14,000 people were also evacuated in the Alicante region due to a forest fire apparently touched off by a downed cable.

The strong winds were also felt across the Mediterranean, with two people killed in the eastern town of Setif when the wall of a house collapsed, civil protection forces said.

urn:contentItem:5V01-0BB1-F031-X2S6-00000-00If extinct animals could be brought back from the dead, should we do it?2018-12-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisIf extinct animals could be brought back from the dead, should we do it?by Natasha Mitchell for Science Friction

Posting pictures of your newborn baby on social media isn't unusual.

But Ben Novak's baby photos are a little stranger than most.

The biologist, a recent first-time father of twins, has taken to tweeting pictures of pigeon hatchlings instead.

The birds are likely the world's first transgenic or genetically engineered pigeons - and Mr Novak hopes they'll help him bring an extinct bird back from the dead.

An expat American - now PhD student at Monash University and CSIRO - Mr Novak works with the global conservation initiative Revive and Restore.

Co-founded by a green philanthropist and a genomics entrepreneur, Revive and Restore's controversial mission is to use biotechnology to "genetically rescue" extinct or endangered animals.

They have the long-gone woolly mammoth, heath hen and passenger pigeon in their sights so far.

But other teams are exploring the possibility of bringing back extinct aurochs (a wild ancestor of domesticated cows), a Galapagos tortoise, the quagga (a South African zebra) and a giant flightless bird once common in New Zealand, the bush moa.

Some wonder if Australia's iconic meat-eating marsupial, the Tasmanian tiger, might even get to roam again one day too.

Why bring back the passenger pigeon?

A pigeon seems like a distinctly unsexy species to start with. But Mr Novak has made it his life's quest to bring back the passenger pigeon by 2025.

The bird was once endemic to the north-eastern United States, and part of Canada.

"150 years ago, there were 5 billion passenger pigeons," Mr Novak said.

"It was probably the most abundant bird on the planet."

The species behaved uniquely. Its entire population amassed together in just two or three giant flocks, sweeping across the sky in staggering formations.

"The largest flock on record may have been 3 to 4 billion birds," he said.

They had a dramatic impact wherever they descended, stripping trees bare, and exposing the forest floor to sunlight and mounds of rich fertiliser in the form of guano - that is, poo.

This promoted the regeneration and renewal of forests as a healthy habitat for other animals.

"They essentially did the same as a hurricane and a forest fire might," Mr Novak told a Science Friction audience at the Melbourne Museum - which holds five passenger pigeon specimens in its collection.

But American's love of pigeon pie eventually wiped the species out altogether.

"There were instances of military units that, if the pigeons hadn't come through, would have starved to death."

The last passenger pigeon, known as Martha, died in captivity at the Cincinnati Zoo in 1914.

Mr Novak believes the environmental impact of the pigeon's demise has been substantial.

"In eastern United States ... there is more forest habitat than there has been in 150 years, in some places, 400 years.

"The forest is coming back [but] most of the species living in the forest are still declining."

What's missing, his investigations suggest, is the pigeon's unique role in the ecosystem.

"It turns out that passenger pigeons were likely the major driver of that regeneration process for ... possibly the last million years."

Mr Novak and colleagues point to what happened when wild wolves, a so-called apex predator, were intentionally returned to Yellowstone National Park in 1995. Their 70-year absence had caused the elk population to explode and overgraze, destroying habitat for other animals.

When the wolves came back, that changed, with a positive flow-on effect for biodiversity in the park: "The beavers came back."

Mr Novak believes de-extinction and so-called "re-wilding" projects must carefully consider what species to target, and not just seek to fulfil a fantastical desire to bring back lost icons.

"[The focus should be] to bring back animals that we know have really important roles that completely transform habitats and ecosystems," he said.

The science of resurrection

The starting point for scientists is to sequence the genome of the extinct animal they want to try to bring back.

In the case of the passenger pigeon, old specimens preserved in museum collections have made this possible.

"You take a little chunk off of its toe, about the size of a pinhead," Mr Novak said.

DNA degrades over time, but it can still be possible to piece together the genetic jigsaw puzzle.

The next step will be to use the tools of biotechnology to recreate the ancient genome in a living animal.

"This is pretty far out. We're not there yet," he said.

If a frozen specimen exists with intact healthy tissue, its cells could potentially be used to create a direct clone of the extinct creature, using the same technique that made Dolly the sheep.

In reproductive cloning - like that used for Dolly - the DNA from a donor's body cell is inserted into the evacuated nucleus of an egg cell, which is then triggered to develop into an embryo and implanted into a mother's womb.

Mr Novak's approach will be to take a species that is genetically similar to the passenger pigeon, the band-tailed pigeon, and use it as a living template.

The gene editing technique known as CRISPR-Cas9 can then be used to cut, snip and sculpt its genome to resemble its long-lost ancestor.

It's early days, but Mr Novak is developing the technique in pigeons, starting with domesticated rock pigeons.

"Band-tailed pigeons are rather rare in captivity," he said.

"Rock pigeons live in higher densities and are easier to work within research settings."

This year he has successfully bred a small number of genetically modified pigeons (16 in total across three batches). They contain the Cas9 gene in their reproductive or germ cells.

This means when they breed they'll pass the gene onto their offspring.

Cas9 is an enzyme that acts like a pair of molecular scissors to cut DNA. It can be used to help delete, edit or insert specific DNA sequences in a genome.

Animal behaviour: it's about more than genes

Recreating an extinct genome is only part of the story. We are all much more than our genes. What about replicating the complex behaviours of extinct animals?

Band-tailed pigeons don't gather in vast, dense flocks as passenger pigeons did, but Mr Novak thinks gene editing could help with that.

"We can edit the DNA of a band-tailed pigeon so that they become hyper-social."

Mr Novak said they are currently mining the genomes to identify mutations for specific traits - for instance, "those that support social breeding behaviour.

"Then we have a species capable of resuming [the passenger pigeon's] role in nature, as long as we nurture it. It's not just about DNA."

A successful result would be a proxy or doppelganger of the extinct passenger pigeon, not a faithful replica.

But that's a long way off - if it ever happens at all.

The de-extinction controversy

Many scientists see de-extinction efforts as fanciful, even maverick work, and a distraction from the real crisis.

"We're living in the middle of an extinction crisis," said Euan Ritchie, a wildlife ecologist at Deakin University.

Professor Ritchie and others point to evidence suggesting we're experiencing the sixth mass extinction event in the Earth's history - on par with what wiped out the dinosaurs 65 million years ago.

But an asteroid isn't responsible this time - we are.

"We are in a stage where humans are really the strongest kind of engineering force in nature, rather than nature itself," said Christy Hipsley, an evolutionary biologist and palaeontologist at the Melbourne Museum.

"A single species having that impact is something that has never happened in all of time."

De-extinction science can never replicate the wonder of evolution, nor how long it takes for species to evolve, Professor Ritchie said.

"Imagine walking into the most beautiful museum, taking all the artworks off the shelves and burning them or throwing them in the bin.

"That's what we're doing.

"We're losing species every day all over the world."

Critics of de-extinction projects share Professor Ritchie's concern that limited resources would be better spent on effective strategies to conserve critically endangered species.

"Don't get me wrong - I would love to see a thylacine [Tasmanian tiger]. Nothing would make me happier," he said.

"[But] we should be focusing on what we have now and asking why species went extinct in the first place."

Would extinct animals be happy in the 21st century?

Some argue we have a moral duty to bring back extinct animals if we had the technology to do so, especially if our actions caused their original demise.

Mr Novak, however, says he isn't motivated by a sense of moral obligation.

"If you go down the road of moral obligation that just leads you into diverting a lot of effort into species that have no hope," he said.

Other scientists have significant concerns about animal welfare consequences of de-extinction efforts.

Even if an animal could be genetically engineered back into existence, would it thrive in the 21st century - especially if its habitat has been destroyed and food sources depleted?

There is a risk a species would be returned only to face extinction again. Or, perhaps worse, become an invasive species itself and cause others to disappear.

"The communities that currently exist have now evolved and adapted in the absence of those species. You're introducing something completely novel to them," Professor Ritchie said.

"There are a whole range of really complex ecological arguments and problems to think about."

Other benefits of de-extinction efforts

Accusations of scientific hubris or maverick research aside, some scientists think investment in de-extinction science might have other benefits.

The techniques that Mr Novak and colleagues are pioneering - for example, gene-editing wild species - may help pull threatened animals back from the brink.

"You can use those same techniques to maybe inject more genetic diversity into a population that's going through a bottleneck," Dr Hipsley suggested.

Dr Hipsley was part of the team that published the genome of the extinct Tasmanian tiger study earlier this year.

She wonders whether the science might offer hope for the Tasmanian devil. Populations of this distant relative of the Tasmanian tiger are being wiped out by a deadly facial tumour disease.

"You could insert resistant genes into a population ... [and] ... release populations of the Tasmanian devil that are resistant to the disease.

"I think there are so many applications that often aren't factored into the cost."

A bleak future without biodiversity

According to recent modelling by Danish researchers, published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, it would take 5 to 7 million years to restore biodiversity levels to what they were before humans evolved, and 3 to 5 million years to recover the species expected to disappear over the next 50 years.

"Think about that for a second. We've been around for less than a million years and think what we've done to the planet," Professor Ritchie said.

If Mr Novak succeeds in resurrecting the passenger pigeon, could this technological fix foster a sense of complacency about saving endangered species?

If biotechnology can bring them back, why should we care about what's being lost?

"Many people have said that conservation needs extinction because without extinction there's no argument for conservation," Professor Ritchie said.

Mr Novak believes we have a vital choice to make.

"We live on this planet in such a dominating way that we get to choose how we live here," he said.

"Do we want trees and prairies to clean our air, or do we want giant atmospheric scrubbers made out of steel and concrete?

"Do we want to live on a planet that's impoverished for the entire duration of our existence or do we want to live in one that is ... rich and diverse?"

urn:contentItem:7X7B-2NP1-2RR2-D2T2-00000-00We must act now or be left behind, warns nation's top scientist2009-12-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4We must act now or be left behind, warns nation's top scientistSINKING THE ETS - CHIEF SCIENTISTBRIDIE SMITH SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY REPORTER

AUSTRALIA'S chief scientist has warned that a failure to act on climate change immediately will place the country at an economic disadvantage and increase the risk of more events like Black Saturday.

On the same day the Government's emissions trading scheme failed to pass the Senate, chief scientist Penny Sackett told The Age the country's economy was dependent on the environment and that there were genuine opportunities for countries wanting to be leaders in "a new global green economy".

She said she had "serious concerns" that Australia would be at "an economic disadvantage if we don't act now".

"By acting now we are learning how to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, we are learning the technologies that we need to do it . . . by starting now we can be leaders in the global green economy. That's where I would like to see Australia," she said.

"All of these things point in the same direction and that is the need to act now."

Stressing she was not a politician â€” Professor Sackett is a physicist by training and astronomer by profession â€” she said Australia going to Copenhagen without a legislated agreement would be a "challenge".

Like the world's leading climate scientists, she argues there are about five years to avoid the dangerous damage if average global temperatures increased by more than 2 degrees above pre-industrial levels. As it stands now, she said, a 1.3-degree rise was all but "locked in".

"To meet the 2 degree target we must halt increases in global emissions by about 2015, and then decrease them dramatically and steadily thereafter."

While Professor Sackett has called for national and global action, she dismissed arguments that Australia was a small player incapable of making a significant contribution.

This will be her key message in a speech in Melbourne today, held by the leadership organisation Australian Davos Connection.

"Australians as individuals can actually make a larger change than individuals in almost anywhere else in the world, if they chose to grasp that opportunity," she said.

According to British analysis, Australia has the world's highest per capita carbon dioxide emissions from energy use, due largely to its coal-based electricity supply. She said scientists internationally were watching Australia, which is considered one of the countries that will feel the greatest impact of climate change.

Research by the CSIRO indicates that the frequency of days with very high or extreme Forest Fire Danger Index ratings is likely to increase by 15 to 70 per cent by 2050 in south-east Australia.

"I would be delighted if we never saw a February like the last one," Professor Sackett said. "But if we do not change the trajectory that we're on, I'm afraid we will see events like Black Saturday more frequently."

urn:contentItem:7X75-SJD0-YB64-43YH-00000-00Chief scientist urges climate change action for sake of economy2009-12-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Chief scientist urges climate change action for sake of economyENVIRONMENT SINKING THE ETSBRIDIE SMITH SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY REPORTER

AUSTRALIA'S chief scientist has warned that a failure to act on climate change immediately will place the country at an economic disadvantage.

On the same day the Government's emissions trading scheme failed to pass the Senate for the second time, chief scientist Penny Sackett told The Age that the country's economy was dependent on the environment and that there were genuine opportunities for countries wanting to be leaders in "a new global green economy".

She said she had "serious concerns" that Australia would be at "an economic disadvantage if we don't act now".

"By acting now we are learning how to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, we are learning the technologies that we need to do it . . . by starting now we can be leaders in the global green economy," she said.

While stressing she was not a politician â€” Professor Sackett is a physicist by training and astronomer by profession â€” she said Australia going to Copenhagen without a legislated agreement would be a "challenge" at the global meeting.

Like the world's leading climate scientists, Professor Sackett argues there are about five years to avoid the dangerous damage generated if average global temperatures increased by more than 2 degrees above pre-industrial levels. As it stands now, she said, a 1.3-degree temperature rise is all but "locked in".

"To meet the 2 degree target we must halt increases in global emissions by about 2015, and then decrease them dramatically and steadily thereafter."

However, while she has called for action on a national and global scale, she dismissed arguments that Australia was a small player incapable of making a significant contribution to a reduction in global emissions.

This will be Professor Sackett's key message at a speech in Melbourne today, held by the leadership organisation Australian Davos Connection.

"Australians as individuals can actually make a larger change than individuals in almost anywhere else in the world, if they chose to grasp that opportunity," she said.

According to British analysis, Australia has the world's highest per capita carbon dioxide emissions from energy use, due largely to its coal-based electricity supply.

She said scientists internationally were watching Australia, which is considered one of the countries which will feel the greatest impact of climate change.

Research by the CSIRO indicates that the frequency of days with very high or extreme Forest Fire Danger Index ratings is likely to increase by 15 to 70 per cent by 2050 in south-east Australia.

"I would be delighted if we never saw a February like the last one," Professor Sackett said. "But if we do not change the trajectory that we're on, I'm afraid we will see events like Black Saturday more frequently."

urn:contentItem:4KCH-PRB0-TX52-H1RR-00000-00Round the World in Eighty Seconds2006-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisWORLDRound the World in Eighty SecondsPg. 13

MATP

Round the World in Eighty Seconds

AUCKLAND: An otter which spent almost a month on the run in New Zealand, frolicking on the beach of Devonport, one of Auckland's top suburbs, has been recaptured.

LONDON: A soprano fired by London's Royal Opera House because of her weight has been rehired after stomach surgery helped her shed 61kg. Deborah Voigt, one of the world's top opera singers, lost her part in Richard Strauss' Ariadne auf Naxos in 2004 because the Royal Opera House wanted a slimmer singer.

HOUSTON: NASA gave great news to Discovery's astronauts, declaring the shuttle's heat shield free of damage which would threaten its return to Earth.

GAZA CITY: An Israeli airstrike last night targeted a car carrying Hamas militants near Gaza City, wounding five people, including an eight-year-old girl, the army and Palestinian health officials said.

WASHINGTON: A top US official said America has the votes in the United Nations for sanctions against North Korea. State Department Undersecretary Nicholas Burns said this on Sunday as other officials pressured China to back such a move. The North Korean ally, along with Russia, has so far resisted this.

HANOI: Two children were killed and two more badly injured when a Vietnam War-era mortar bomb they were playing with exploded in central Vietnam.

LISBON: Six firemen died in a forest fire burning out of control in central Portugal, local media said. The dead were five Chileans and one Portuguese. Flames were fanned by strong winds.

CAIRO: Workers at 25 Egyptian newspapers went on strike on Sunday as the legislature in Cairo appeared ready to approve a law which leaves journalists more vulnerable to fines and jail time for critical reports on finances and behaviour of government officials.

MADRID: A gay couple and a lesbian couple tied the knot in Valencia during Pope Benedict XVI's visit to the Spanish city. Jose Francisco Lamo and Luisa Notario pledged undying love to their partners as elsewhere in the city the Pope said mass before more than a million at the climax of his two-day visit to Catholic Spain. He praised marriage between man and woman as ''a great good for all humanity''.

urn:contentItem:511B-63S1-F0JP-W0CK-00000-00SMART TEEN COMEDY A RISQUE BUSINESS2010-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisEXTRAHITPg. 45SMART TEEN COMEDY A RISQUE BUSINESSLEIGH PAATSCH

Easy A (M)

***1/2

Director: Will Gluck (Fired Up!)

Starring: Emma Stone, Penn Badgley, Aly Michalka, Amanda Bynes, Patricia Clarkson (above right), Stanley Tucci, Thomas Haden Church

A hard way to make good of a bad reputation

THE best teen comedy of the year not to feature any superheroes, magic powers or rampant violence whatsoever -- yes, Kick-Ass and Scott Pilgrim, that means you -- Easy A is witty, wise and not afraid to walk on the wild side once in a while.

The central figure in a tangled tale of enhanced notoriety at the expense of repressed chastity is 16-year-old student Olive Penderghast (Emma Stone).

Though highly intelligent, searingly self-aware and funny to a fault, Olive makes one heck of a dumb mistake when a throwaway excuse to cover a dull weekend spent at home marks her out as the school tramp.

A forest fire of hearsay breaks out, fanned by social networking and text-message blasts. Having been one of the school's uncool for so long, Olive is ill-equipped to douse the blaze.

Make that incurably ill-equipped. Without having once sacrificed her virtue -- which remains intact throughout Easy A -- Olive becomes embroiled in a scheme where she feigns intimacy with the male freaks and geeks of school.

In the wrong hands, there are any number of seedy places Easy A could have strayed. However, the movie rarely falters in its intent to entertain viewers and explore an unusual story with its integrity completely intact.

Key to Easy A's well-earned positive outcome is the break-out performance of Emma Stone as Olive.

Not only does the lead performer conquer a deceptively demanding role with complete aplomb (not a world away from what Ellen Page achieved with Juno a few years ago).

What really impresses you about Stone is the precision of her delivery and the sharpness of her comic timing. A star primed to go to the next level? You bet.

Equally strong is the support cast -- all of whom respond to the vibrancy of the Easy A screenplay with unmistakable enthusiasm.

Be sure to keep an ear on the banter shared by Patricia Clarkson and Stanley Tucci as Olive's endearingly unconventional parents. They're so good you could watch an entire film of them simply standing around talking.

Whatever you do, don't give in to the inkling we might have a girl's own Superbad on our hands here. Easy A is much less coarse and a lot more cultured than that.

Still, there can be no getting around the fact the plot concerns a teenage female who somehow finds herself pretending to be promiscuous for fun and profit. Not all viewers will be prepared to play along with such risque business. Fair enough.

Those who are game will be rewarded with a smart, sussed take on the life of the modern teenager.

VISIT www.easya.com.au

urn:contentItem:4DJN-12V0-015H-90WR-00000-00<published>2004-10-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL; Pg. 11</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Helicopter on standby to aid desperate forest battle Thunderstorms help fire fight</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>DAMIAN McINTYRE</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FAVOURABLE weather conditions are expected to help fire crews battling a large fire on the North-East Coast.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The blaze at Doctors Peak has already burnt about 2500ha near St Helens and is moving toward the coast.</p><p nitf:lede="true">On Thursday police asked people to leave the area from Binalong Bay to The Gardens after the fire in the Doctors Peak forest reserve near Ansons Bay moved quickly after being fanned by winds.</p><p>Forestry Tasmania's incident controller for the Bass region, Garry Richardson, said crews were getting the upper hand on the fire.</p><p>Extra crews had been brought in to help with containment lines and firefighters in the area now numbered about 40.</p><p>"I think we are on top of it more than what we were yesterday [Thursday]," Mr Richardson said.</p><p>A large part of the fire is in an inaccessible area and a helicopter is on standby. There is no threat to property.</p><p>The weather bureau yesterday forecast showers and occasional isolated thunderstorms in the North-East.</p><p>Severe weather meteorologist Paul Fox-Hughes said blustery south-westerly winds had eased off yesterday afternoon.</p><p>"The winds should be fairly light for the next few days," he said.</p><p>A large fire at Saddleback Forest, near Mathinna in the Fingal Valley, and another smaller fire at Pigs Rd, 8km south of Mathinna, are under control.</p><p>The Saddleback Forest fire has burnt about 800ha of native forest and the Pigs Rd fire about 150ha.</p><p>Forestry Tasmania Bass region manager Steve Manson said both fires were under control.</p><p>"Fire crews will be mopping up over the next couple of days and will continue to monitor the fires," he said.</p><p>Investigators are at both fires trying to determine their cause. Arson has not been ruled out as the cause of the fire at Doctors Peak.</p><p> Another fire at Bicheno which started earlier this week has burnt about 1400ha and threatens homes and shacks.</p><p>Tasmanian Fire Service spokesman Ken Burns said about 95 per cent of the fire had been contained.</p><p>A fire permit period is in place for the North-East, East Coast, Midlands and southern Tasmania.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:511B-BT91-F0JP-W179-00000-00This one's an easy winner2010-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisSUPPLEMENTPg. 21This one's an easy winnerLEIGH PAATSCH

Easy A(M)

***1/2

Director: Will Gluck (Fired Up!)

Starring: Emma Stone, Penn Badgley, Aly Michalka, Amanda Bynes, Patricia Clarkson, Stanley Tucci, Thomas Haden Church.

Making good of a bad reputation ... the hard way

THE best teen comedy of the year may not feature any superheroes, magic powers or any rampant violence whatsoever yes, Kick-Ass and Scott Pilgrim, that means you.

Easy A is witty, wise, and not afraid to take a walk on the wild side once in a while.

The central figure in a tangled tale of enhanced notoriety at the expense of repressed chastity is 16-year-old student Olive Penderghast (Emma Stone).

Though highly intelligent, searingly self-aware and funny to a fault, Olive makes one heck of a dumb mistake when a single throwaway excuse to cover a dull weekend spent at home marks her out as the school tramp.

A forest fire of hearsay breaks out, fanned by social networking and text-message blasts. Having been one of the school's uncool for so long, Olive is ill-equipped to douse the blaze.

Make that incurably ill-equipped. Without having once sacrificed her virtue which remains intact throughout Easy A Olive becomes embroiled in a scheme where she feigns intimacy with the male freaks and geeks of school.

In the wrong hands, there are any number of seedy places Easy A could have strayed. However, the movie rarely falters in its intent to both entertain viewers and explore an unusual story with its integrity completely intact.

Key to Easy A's well-earned positive outcome is the breakout performance of Emma Stone as Olive.

Not only does the lead performer conquer a deceptively demanding role with complete aplomb (not a world away from what Ellen Page achieved with Juno a few years ago), but what really impresses about Stone is the precision of her delivery and the sharpness of her comic timing. A star primed to go to the next level? You bet.

Equally strong is the support cast, all of whom respond to the vibrancy of the Easy A screenplay with unmistakable enthusiasm.

Be sure to keep an ear on the banter shared by Patricia Clarkson and Stanley Tucci as Olive's endearingly unconventional parents they're so good you could pretty much watch an entire film of them simply standing around talking.

Whatever you do, don't give in to the inkling we might have a girl's own Superbad on our hands here. Easy A is much less coarse and a lot more cultured than that.

Still, there can be no getting around the fact the plot concerns a teenage female who somehow finds herself pretending to be promiscuous for fun and profit.

It's easy to see not all viewers will be prepared to play along with such risque business, and fair enough.

But those who are game will be rewarded with a smart, sussed take on the life of the modern teenager.

urn:contentItem:4D9G-GJX0-015G-X2MC-00000-00<published>2004-09-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FOREIGN; Pg. 25</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Nuclear test explosion fears</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SEOUL: A large explosion occurred in the northern part of North Korea, sending a huge column of smoke into the air on an important anniversary of the communist regime, a South Korean news agency reported yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The South Korean Government said it was trying to confirm the report of an explosion on Thursday in Yanggang province, near the border with China.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Yonhap news agency carried conflicting reports from unidentified sources, with one in Washington saying the incident could be related to a natural disaster such as a forest fire.</p><p>It also cited a diplomatic source in Seoul as raising the possibility of an accident or a nuclear test. Yonhap later quoted Kim Jong-min, spokesman for the presidential office, as saying: "Currently, we are trying to find out in detail the exact character, cause and size of the accident, but we don't think North Korea conducted a nuclear test."</p><p>Although North Korea is believed to be developing nuclear weapons, international experts would likely have been able to detect the test if one had occurred.</p><p>"We understand that a mushroom-shaped cloud about 3.5 to 4km in diameter was monitored during the explosion," the source in Seoul told Yonhap. Yonhap described the source as "reliable".</p><p>Thursday was the anniversary of North Korea's founding on September 9, 1948. Leader Kim Jong Il uses the occasion to stage performances and other events to bolster loyalty among the impoverished North Korean population. Yonhap's diplomatic source in Seoul said the explosion took place "not far" from a military base that holds ballistic missiles. The damage and crater left by the explosion in Kim Hyong Jik county was big enough to be noticed by a satellite, a source in Beijing told Yonhap.</p><p>On April 22, train wagons at a railway station exploded in the North Korean town of Ryongchon, killing 160 people and injuring an estimated 1300, according to some estimates. The blast was believed to have been sparked by a train laden with oil and chemicals that hit powerlines.</p><p>The explosion on Thursday was bigger than the Ryongchon train explosion, which devastated a wide area.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4TTX-8950-TXX1-F16M-00000-00health matters2008-11-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisSUPPLEMENTPg. 16health matterswith Nicola Conville

"My own prescription for health is less paperwork and more running barefoot through the grass." Leslie Grimutter, poet

Read this: Flight Of The Hummingbird by Michael Yahgulanaas (Hachette Livre, $22.99)

This little book contains a simple parable with a strong environmental message. It tells the tale of a hummingbird who tries to put out a forest fire by carrying drops of water in her beak, highlighting the power of taking small steps to achieve a big goal, and reminding us that we all need to help to create the world we want for ourselves and our children.

Six ways to boost your fitness

1 Write your exercise plans in your diary and stick to them like you would any other appointment.

2Mix up your routine to maintain your interest and stop your body from reaching a plateau.

3Turn off the TV one night and dedicate that time to a game of tennis with friends.

4Make one lunchbreak an activehour - go for a brisk walk in thepark before eating.

5Take any opportunity for incidental exercise - see every set of stairs asa chance to tone your thighs and butt.

6Whenever you can, clench your muscles in your core - your butt, stomach or your pelvic floor.

Beauty pack Summer's nearly here and my thoughts are turning to holidays. But don't rely on hotel shampoos and conditioners - they're often little better than washing-up liquid. Try the new all-organic travel pack from Endota instead. It contains everything you need for a long-haul flight or a weekend away: Native Mint shampoo and conditioner, River Salt and Desert Lime shower gel and Lilly Pilly body moisturiser. Available from Endota spas nationally for $35. Visit www.endota.com.au

Everything in order

Anyone can get die suddenly, and if our affairs are not in order, it means loved ones are often left to make tough decisions. Affairs In Order is a do-it-yourself pack which helps you organise your financial, health and personal affairs. From $89 per pack, visit www.affairsinorder.com.au or call (02) 9660 1045.

Furry friends

Protect your pet from ticks and fleas the natural way with a Ticlace - a sturdy Baltic amber necklace which can be worn by dogs and cats of all sizes. As the amber rubs against the animal's fur, it creates a mild static electrical charge, completely undetectable to the animal, which gives the tick a shock. It also releases a resinous scent, which deters ticks and fleas from staying in the animal's coat. The Ticlace is effective within two to three weeks and lasts for up to 12 months of continuous use. From $39, visit www.ticlace.com for more information.

Pg. 7</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>New crisis  as Borneo  fires claim  first victim </nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>PETER ALFORD</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">in Jakarta</p><p nitf:lede="true">RESURGENT bushfires in Borneo claimed their first victim as authorities warned the situation is again deteriorating into crisis.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Indonesia's Antara newsagency reported the death of an unnamed person from respiratory illness in the East Kalimantan town of Samarinda, after exposure to choking smoke from huge fires burning at Bukit Soeharto to the south and Kutai national park to the north.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>Antara said thousands of Kalimantan residents were now suffering from asthma attacks and other respiratory complaints as more than 1000 fires blazed across the east and central regions of Borneo island.</p><p> International experts are warning the Borneo situation is potentially worse than the catastrophic fires between September and November, blanketing much of the Indonesian archipelago, Singapore and Malaysia in a choking smog.</p><p> The region's worst postwar ecological disaster, the fires and haze caused billions of dollars of losses and damage and were blamed for more than 40 deaths from respiratory problems in Kalimantan, Sumatra and Irian Jaya.</p><p> The monsoon rains that helped douse last year's fires have retreated in East Kalimantan and the area is again in the grip of a drought that makes any fire outbreak "almost impossible to control", said Hartmut Abberger, a German official with the Samarinda-based Integrated Forest Fire Management Project.</p><p> "It is much worse than last year and it is getting worse," he said.</p><p> The provincial government has distributed more than 20,000 gas masks in Samarinda, where visibility on Friday was reduced to a few metres before afternoon winds cleared the smog.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:465Y-F6K0-015H-906R-00000-00<published>2002-07-01T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 12</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>QUICK NEWS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Train bombed</p><p nitf:lede="true">A BOMB went off yesterday on a railway line as a train passed over it just north of Lod in central Israel, damaging one of the carriages. Four passengers were taken to hospital suffering from shock. Police believe the charge was planted during the night.</p><p>Bush health OK</p><p>DOCTORS yesterday gave US President George W. Bush a clean bill of health after screening his colon at Camp David. During the procedure, which required general anaesthetic, he ceded power to Vice-President Dick Cheney. "No polyps were found, no abnormalities were found," Air Force doctor Colonel Richard Tubb said.</p><p>Blaze arrest</p><p>A MAN was arrested yesterday for allegedly causing the first of two fires that merged into the blaze that destroyed more than 400 homes in eastern Arizona. The man will be arraigned before a federal magistrate in Flagstaff to answer charges relating to Arizona's largest recorded forest fire.</p><p>Ranger sacked</p><p> THE US Forest Service has sacked Terry Barton, the employee charged with starting the largest wildfire since Colorado became a state. The blaze burned 55,441ha and destroyed at least 133 homes south-west of Denver. Barton, 38, has pleaded innocent to four federal charges, including arson.</p><p>Frisbee king dies</p><p>ARTHUR "Spud" Melin, co-founder of the toy company that introduced the world to the frisbee, hula hoop and other faddish gems of American pop culture, has died. He was 77 and had Alzheimer's disease. Melin, who started toy giant Wham-O in 1948 with his boyhood friend Richard Knerr, died yesterday in Costa Mesa, California.</p><p>Hot car deaths</p><p>TWO young children died at the weekend when they were left alone in a hot car for more than three hours by their mother, who was having her hair done in Southfield, Michigan. She is being held on an open charge of murder, pending a review by prosecutors.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P85-11H0-TXN5-R373-00000-00THUMBS1996-02-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisTHE GUIDEPg. 25THUMBSBRUCE ELDER

DOWN

BAYWATCH: Ten, 7.30 pm. This is the end of civilisation as we know it: an episode of Baywatch without Pamela Anderson and, an even greater tragedy, one of the world's greatest actresses has changed her name. Ladies and gentlemen, let us all put our hands together for Mrs Pamela Lee, wife of Tommy and a woman not afraid to embrace the surname of her spouse. Oh, incidentally, this episode, titled "Hot Stuff", is not about the women on the beach. It's about a forest fire. Although Pamela does not appear, that Aussie hunk, Jaason Simmons (has he got a stutter or is he a relative of Siimon Reynolds?), puts in a shimmering performance.

DOWN

GLADIATORS - International Series: Seven, 6.30 pm. Fifty million people around the world watch Gladiators every week. Fifty million people can be wrong. Watch it and marvel at your fellow homo sapiens. Grab a copy of Hamlet and start reading, "What a piece of work is man! How noble in reason! ... in action how like an angel" and wonder whether Shakespeare would have written those lines after an hour of Gladiators. Mind you, when the Aussie guy is on the rings with that big fella wrapped around him like an orangutan on heat, well - I watched!

UP

LIQUID TELEVISION: SBS, 9 pm. A welcome repeat of a series which pushes television to the experimental limits. Not all of it works, but there's enough to leave you marvelling.

urn:contentItem:3S05-HXN0-0048-T2YT-00000-00<published>1998-02-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>MORE SEVERE DROUGHT FORECAST IN INDONESIA IN 1998</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ll <emphasis typeStyle="it">d </emphasis></p><p>nv</p><p nitf:lede="true">SAMARINDA, Indonesia, Feb 9 Asia Pulse - This year's drought may be more severe than last year's, according to the National Disaster Control Coordinating Agency (Bakornas PB).</p><p nitf:lede="true"><emphasis typeStyle="it"> Quoting the results of studies conducted by a number of research centers in Indonesia and the United States, the agency's deputy chief Adang Ruchiatna said this year's drought was predicted to last longer than last year's when hundreds of hectares of forests and woodlands were razed by fire. </emphasis></p><p>Adang, who is also a member of the steering committee of the national forest and woodland fire control agency, said the 1998 drought would be compounded by the El Nino weather pattern which was difficult to predict.</p><p> "We earlier predicted that rain would fall in January 1998. Instead there came a drought with tens of thousands of hectares of forests burned, making the 1998 drought worse," he said.</p><p> Meanwhile, Ludwig Schindler, team leader of the Integrated Forest Fire Management Project-Deutsche Gesellscalf Fire Technische Zusammenarbeit (IFFM-GTZ), shared Adang's view, saying in East Kalimantan alone, an estimated 15,000 hectares of forests and woodlands were destroyed by fire last month.</p><p> He added that nearly 5,000 hectares of forests were still on fire.</p><p> Citing satellite observations made by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) in Samarinda, he said thousands of sites had been identified as hotspots since early this year.</p><p> Fires destroyed hundreds of thousands of hectares of forests in East Kalimantan over the past seven years. The biggest forest fires occurred in 1992 when 418,920 hectares were hit.</p><p> (ANTARA)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3S05-HXN0-0048-T2YT-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="278"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. The proposed Project would strengthen cooperation among affected ASEAN countries through: (i) short-term measures required to support early finalization of the Action Plan, and (ii) medium-term measures required to support enhanced understanding of the transboundary atmospheric haze pollution and strengthen the concerned institutions in implementation and institutionalized monitoring of the Action Plan. </emphasis></p><p> Procurement: An estimated input of about 54 person-months would be needed, comprising 12 person-months of international and 42 person-months of regional consultants. Expertise would be required in the fields of macro and resource economics and policy, institutional development, policy and legislation, forest fire prevention and control, computerized early fire warning and information management, computer modeling of air pollution, and social and public health impact assessment.    <br/> Project Processing Stage: Staff Review Committee Meeting to be scheduled.</p><p> Status of Consulting Services: No action has yet been taken to recruit consultants.</p><p> Project Officer:</p><p> Mr. S. Tahir Qadri (632-6774)</p><p> Environment Division</p><p> ASIA PULSE</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3RYC-S5X0-0048-T2KN-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="343"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty.
