urn:contentItem:5MWJ-FT81-JCM0-63WP-00000-00Life after Black Saturday: 'I sincerely believed I was losing my mind'2017-02-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisLife after Black Saturday: 'I sincerely believed I was losing my mind'By Jane Cowan

As one of the fire chiefs in charge on Black Saturday, Ewan Waller was hit hard by the tragic events that unfolded and says he is yet to fully recover from the emotional toll. He speaks to Jane Cowan in her seven-part series revisiting Victoria's worst natural disaster.

Ewan Waller yells at the kelpies in the back of the ute as he trundles along the ridge line between his pastures. Every bend bears a memory.

"You've got to be careful you don't become a bore because you're always talking about things that happened," he said.

The Wallers go back generations here, in this hill country where Ewan now runs Angus cattle and Merino sheep.

Google calls it Iguana Creek, but he thinks of it more as Glenaladale. More than three hours east of Melbourne and still half an hour from Bairnsdale.

On 660 acres, the former fire chief breeds his own weaners and lambs. His wool has topped the market for the last couple of years.

Ewan describes his father as a true bushman who furnished him with his earliest understandings of fire and its role in the Australian landscape.

"You don't fear the bush, you understand the bush and how it works - what works and what doesn't work.

"My dad would carry a box of matches and he would often burn, he'd burn the tussocks or he'd burn a heap of rubbish, or whatever, and he knew how to do it and do it right."

Ewan had been Victoria's forest fire chief, head of the-then Department of Sustainability and Environment, for three years when Black Saturday hit.

Among the prominent leaders on the day, he stood out. Others including his CFA counterpart Russell Rees, with whom he remains friends, defended their actions or attacked the legitimacy of the inquiry.

Ewan was willing to say sorry. He remembers it as an excruciating period.

"I had to really work at not getting too emotional about it. I could have cracked up really easily.

"For example, when a firefighter got killed and I had to do just a little [media interview] grab saying 'this has hit us hard and we're feeling it'.

"I rehearsed for hours that night before just to get a sentence-and-a-half out. And that takes a hell of a toll on you.

"You cope with it almost by numbing down. You shut down to a lot of your emotions or you can't keep going. As another senior manager said, 'We can't sook over this. We've got to keep our heads up, we've got to lead.'"

Meditation helped. Relaxation techniques. Some professional help.

The Waller family home was burnt out when Ewan was a teenager, but it took Black Saturday to join the dots, to realise how deeply it had affected him. He remembers his dad labouring for days afterwards to prop up fences and keep stock.

A truckload of hay turned up from one of the big stock and station agents. Surrounded by blackened paddocks, the driver handed his father the bill in the same breath as the help.

"You know you just say, 'Where's your heart, what are you doing?'"

Ewan admits he's yet to fully recover from Black Saturday. It's changed who he is. There are mental and even physical scars - a deep wearing down.

"The personal impacts show up in what to me were quite surprising ways. One of the impacts was I couldn't concentrate.

"After Black Saturday and after the royal commission I'd look at a page of technical writing where I used to be able to scan and get the gist of it within a very short period of time and I found I couldn't.

"If I turned the page I'd forget what was written on the first page. That's certainly quite common in trauma events where you lose the ability to concentrate and memory and short-term recall but it was surprising to me.

"I sincerely believed I was losing my mind because I'd been very sharp and could pull things together quickly. I couldn't do it.

"And one of the consequences of that was I was managing poorly. I couldn't read and I couldn't convey as I believed I had to. That's one of the real disappointments, the last couple of years of my career in the public service weren't good."

Department managers started fighting and the teamwork disintegrated.

"You couldn't trust the person sitting beside you, that's about how bad it was. There was no common cause... a lot of good people suffered.

"There was a lot of stress and a lot of strain, a lot of people not knowing what to do. The problem was so immense, the community expecting silver bullets and they weren't there."

The bush is a balm.

The drive from Melbourne to Gippsland is a slow unravelling as the suburbs turn to bush. The flick of a lyrebird, a wallaby crashing across the road.

The scent of the eucalypts is still enough to make Ewan's breath catch. The musky smell at the head of a gully. The dogwoods.

And then the dappled light once the truck leaves the cleared land. The loosening in the muscles, the mind.

These days Ewan uses his regrets as motivation.

Between the weeds and the fencing, reports are written at the kitchen table in the old farmhouse where he lives on the property that was once his father's, where his parents began their married life in a bark hut that was later razed in a bushfire that burnt from Licola to Bruthen in 1965.

As a bushfire management consultant, he travels the country working with state agencies and private landowners, spreading knowledge he hopes will restore the confidence to manage forest fuels by preventative burning.

"I think a lot of it came back to the fire agencies scaring people. They didn't really understand bushfire so they then said, 'Don't anybody do it. If you light a fire on your property and it gets away, you'll be prosecuted.'

"And so now we've got a culture that's scared of fire rather than respecting fire and saying it's just part of the Australian landscape, respect it, use it but don't be scared of it.

"I really am concerned about the ability to manage the bush. I look now at the modern practitioner who looks at the computer and goes to a meeting in Melbourne or the regional centre and it's a different life."

Ewan says it was his knowledge of the bush and the push to get things in better shape that motivates him to go on.

"The best preparation we can do is do it now, in the quiet before it turns bad again. And it will, it will turn bad again."

Former CFA fire chief Russell Rees was invited but declined to participate in this story.

Part five: former police chief Christine Nixon

urn:contentItem:55BM-8NN1-F0J6-J3W1-00000-00Blackout probe sheds little light2007-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Blackout probe sheds little lightDuncan Hughes

A report by the electricity market operator into a blackout in January that caused peak-hour chaos and millions of dollars' damages to Melbourne businesses has failed to provide clear recommendations on what to do if it happens again.

The National Electricity Market Management Company (Nemmco) report into the causes of the January 16 outages and its own reactions - the second of four reports on the blackout - describes the situation as unprecedented and concludes an even worse situation was prevented by its response.

But state opposition spokesman Robert Clark said it was hard to see what firm action Nemmco and others were taking to minimise the possibility of such incidents.

"While Nemmco is recognising the growing seriousness of incidents, the report does not make clear what needs to be done," he said.

The state government declined to comment on the market operator's recommendations until after the publication of additional reports by the Australian Energy Regulator and Department of Primary Industry. The first report was conducted by Vencorp, the Victorian energy networks corporation responsible for the efficient operation of the gas and electricity markets.

Power was cut to about 690,000 electricity customers, including 70,000 businesses, and Melbourne's central business district was disrupted after a bushfire cut the main power links between Snowy River power stations and Melbourne at about 4pm, causing a shortfall of about 2200 megawatts. Generating capacity was restored just after 6pm but it took several hours for all domestic lines to be operating.

"All the lines in the interconnect tripped due to a significant amount of smoke and ash from a pine forest fire close to the easement (carrying the distribution power lines)," Nemmco chief executive Leslie Hosking said.

Mr Hosking, whose role was to assess the reliability of the power system, said it had reacted appropriately to a major shock, preventing a systemic breakdown similar to that experienced in August 2003 in the United States and Canada.

"We will look at trying to have better satellite and helicopter information, despite the problem of thick smoke," Mr Hosking said.

The market operator will also improve its software systems.

Meanwhile, the Energy Users Association, which speaks to big power users, will conduct another inquiry, partly funded by energy regulators, into the high prices in the national electricity market.

urn:contentItem:45PT-RF00-015G-T07M-00000-00<published>2002-05-01T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>HOME ENTERTAINMENT GUIDE; Pg. H09</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>What a sight for dinosaur eyes</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>TIM JAMIESON</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">WHERE else can you find man-eating apes and dinosaurs chasing a group of eccentric explorers?</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The Lost World puts into graphic pictures what Sir Arthur Conan Doyle wrote in his 1912 dinosaur fantasy.</p><p>The two-part epic, starting tonight, was filmed in New Zealand and the stunning digital effects were provided by Tim Haines of the acclaimed Walking with Dinosaurs.</p><p> The action-adventure is helped along by names such as Bob Hoskins, Peter Falk and James Fox leading the cast.</p><p> Consider this a treat. It is so good the BBC screened it over two nights on Christmas Day and Boxing Day.</p><p> The Lost World follows British explorers searching for dinosaurs on a plateau in the Amazonian jungle.</p><p> For viewers who feel they have seen enough dinosaurs, The Lost World gives Jurassic Park a run for its money, and all that derring-do makes it great fun for young and old.</p><p> During filming, the effects people marked out with poles and balls where the computer-generated animals would be.</p><p> Combining computer images with live action was done thousands of kilometres away in London.</p><p> Actor Tom Ward, who plays daredevil Lord Roxton, didn't see many dinosaurs on location.</p><p> "You just sit there and a guy runs up and down with an orange ball saying, 'That's the head, that's the tail' and then we all gawk at that. You feel a bit of a dork."</p><p> Ward says of his character: "He's outgoing and quite tough. He's good with a gun, he likes the girls and he likes chucking himself into dangerous situations."</p><p> And there were plenty of those.</p><p> A tornado forced the cast and crew to evacuate the set and on another occasion they had to change hotels because of a forest fire.</p><p>The Lost World, Channel 2, tonight and tomorrow, 8.30</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4597-3NS0-0197-D559-00000-00<published>1997-12-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Summer Fire Safety Advertising Feature; How to avoid;<br/>Wildfire woe</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE Country Fire Service has called on all rural property owners and</p><p nitf:lede="true">Hills residents to partner it in helping to prevent "Wildfire" this</p><p nitf:lede="true">summer.</p><p nitf:lede="true">In announcing the CFS 1997/98 public information Wildfire campaign,</p><p nitf:lede="true">CFS chief executive officer Mr Stuart Ellis advised that a market</p><p nitf:lede="true">survey undertaken in February had produced some distressing findings.</p><p>It showed 78 per cent of rural and Hills zone residents interviewed</p><p>did not believe their properties faced a high fire risk.</p><p>"The reality is that the majority of rural property and Hills zone</p><p>residents are at risk and therefore must prepare themselves for the</p><p>worst," Mr Ellis said.</p><p>"The CFS strategy therefore highlighted that when a fire gets out of</p><p>control it becomes wild and we are all put in danger. This year we are</p><p>calling the danger Wildfire _ not bushfire, or grass fire, or forest</p><p>fire or farm fire, but Wildfire _ and you must prepare yourself for</p><p>the worst. The next step is to extend our reach and develop our</p><p>working relationships with local councils to assist in the</p><p>distribution of relevant information."</p><p>Advice will be mailed to rural property owners and Hills residents,</p><p>including a personal letter with a six-page Wildfire leaflet. It</p><p>covers:</p><p>How to clean up around your property and the equipment and clothing</p><p>you need to have at the ready.</p><p>What to do in the event of a fire _ should you stay or evacuate.</p><p>What to do after the fire has passed _ such as patrolling and putting</p><p>out spot fires.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:7W89-KVX0-YBDY-R2GV-00000-00Push for trials of digital fire spotter2009-07-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. 9Push for trials of digital fire spotterGary Hughes

KEVIN Rudd will be asked to help fund an Australian trial of an automated German bushfire detection system based on technology developed for NASA to map the surface of Mars.

Federal Liberal MP Fran Bailey, whose Victorian electorate of McEwen covers many of the communities devastated on Black Saturday, said the digital sensing system could detect blazes from up to 40km away within minutes, and could be vital in preventing bushfires.

She said she would ask the Prime Minister to provide partial funding for a trial of the Firewatch system developed by the German Aerospace Institute, which she saw in operation during a trip to Europe to study bushfire prevention.

Ms Bailey told The Australian she would also be advocating radical fuel reduction methods used in Portugal and Germany, where vegetation is cut back for 10m on each side of the roads to provide safe escape routes.

European countries made saving lives the top priority in their forest fire strategies, Ms Bailey said. ``Their thinking is the opposite of what we have been doing in Australia,'' she said from London, as she neared the end of her month-long European study tour.

``When I tell them there are local government authorities in Australia that will not allow people to clear around their homes and have prosecuted people for removing dead wood on roadsides, they look at me as if I'd just arrived from outer space. They take fuel reduction very seriously.''

The Victorian bushfires royal commission has been told 21 people died in or near vehicles or on roadways on Black Saturday after being caught by firefronts as they tried to flee.

Ms Bailey said the German remote Firewatch system, which uses electronic camera sensors on unmanned towers, had reduced the amount of forest burnt in parts of that country by more than 90 per cent.

The system, which operates around the clock, can automatically detect small plumes of smoke from up to 40km away, pinpoint the location and estimate the size of the fire.

Ms Bailey said she would brief Mr Rudd on the system after she returned home at the weekend.

The move came as Victorian Premier John Brumby warned that his state could be facing a catastrophe similar to the Black Saturday fires, which killed 173 people, in the coming bushfire season.

A leaked report from the Victorian Department of Sustainability and Environment says low winter rainfall has increased the likelihood of a fire season ``with the greatest potential loss to life and property''.

``We may be lucky, we may get a wet winter and a wet spring and we may have a relatively good fire season, but all of the advice at the moment is that this will be as bad, if notworse, than anything we've seen in the past decade,'' Mr Brumby said.

urn:contentItem:7W93-C7K0-Y9B7-504S-00000-00Highlights of the AAP world wire at 08:00 Aug 22009-08-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSHighlights of the AAP world wire at 08:00 Aug 2

  HIGHLIGHTS WORLD (ATTN EDITORS)
Highlights of the AAP world file at 08:00 Aug 2 2009.
US: Man in custody after airport bomb scare in NYC
   NEW YORK, Aug 1 AP - The central terminal at New York's LaGuardia Airport was evacuated on Saturday morning after a man entered the building with a fake bomb in a bag, police said. (US FAKE sent at 02:56, 325 words.)


ASIA: One French, three US soldiers killed in Afghan attacks
   KABUL, Aug 1 AFP - A French soldier and three US troops were killed in insurgent attacks in Afghanistan on Saturday, the military said, after deaths in July reportedly reached 75, the highest since 2001. (AFGHAN UNREST sent at 02:27, 426 words.)
US: Obama hails action on health care bill
   WASHINGTON, Aug 1 AFP - US President Barack Obama has hailed a key congressional committee's approval of a bill embracing his plan to overhaul the US health care system as a "historic consensus". (US HEALTH sent at 00:56, 353 words.)
MID: Iran says three US nationals arrested near Iraq border
   TEHRAN, Aug 1 AFP - Iran has arrested three Americans who "infiltrated" from Iraq, state television said on Saturday, as Washington sought confirmation those picked up are backpackers who reportedly strayed across the border. (IRAN TOURISTS Update sent at 05:37, 612 words.)
AFR: Nigeria police say suspected Islamists arrested
   MAIDUGURI, Nigeria, Aug 1 AFP - Police in Nigeria say they have arrested dozens of members of an Islamist sect and freed hundreds of civilians kidnapped by the group, after security forces crushed its violent uprising. (NIGERIA UNREST sent at 04:29, 523 words.)
EUR: Fire in Canary Islands forces evacuation of 4,000
   LA PALMA, Canary Islands, Aug 1 AP - A forest fire fanned by high winds has forced the evacuation of about 4,000 residents on the Canary Island of La Palma, the Spanish government says. (SPAIN FIRE sent at 03:49, 288 words.)
MID: Iran's Rafsanjani denies pact with opposition leaders
   TEHRAN, Aug 1 AFP - Powerful Iranian cleric Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani on Saturday branded as a "lie" a claim made in court that he had entered a pact with ex-president Mohammad Khatami and opposition leader Mir Hossein Mousavi. (IRAN TRIAL sent at 03:37, 332 words.)
EUR: Couples wed on boat during Amsterdam gay pride
   AMSTERDAM, Aug 1 AFP - Five gay Dutch-American couples tied the knot aboard a boat on Saturday during Amsterdam's gay pride festival, as thousands of revellers took to waterborne floats on the city's historic canals. (DUTCH GAY sent at 04:14, 325 words.)
UK: Man seeks exile on Scottish island to quit smoking
   LONDON, Aug 1 AFP - A former banker who is unable to quit smoking is to spend August on a remote uninhabited Scottish island in a bid to break the habit, newspapers reported on Saturday. (UK QUIT sent at 01:21, 304 words.)

SUNDAY BEST

ANGIE HART City

Former Frente frontwoman performs. She's been solo for ages, so why even mention it? Anyway, she plays a free show today at Victoria Market, 513 Elizabeth St. LLOYD

COLE Thornbury

Wow, Fred Maher is on drums in the Small Ensemble! New album is Broken Record, but set includes Forest Fire and Rattlesnakes. 859 High St. 7pm. $57-$92.

FAITHLESS Flemington

Techno giants sharing the Good Vibrations bill with Phoenix, Nas, Erykah Badu and Ludacris. Flemington Racecourse. 12pm-10pm. $149.90.

GRANT SMILLIE St Kilda

TV rock star, Ruby Rose sidekick and the hardest-working DJ in town -- or so he says. With supersinger Zoe Badwi. Prince Bandroom, 29 Fitzroy St. $20. 1pm.

8 BIT LOVE St Kilda

Electro-rock kids 8 Bit Love play The Push stage for emerging talent at the St Kilda Festival. Bamboos and Tim Finn play the main stage. Beach foreshore. 12-5pm.

SPRINGS FESTIVAL Taradale

Food, wine, puddings, oils and preserves -- and, er, a whip-cracking demonstration -- at a free-flowing spring. Mineral Springs Reserve. 10am-4pm.

... AND BEYOND

MON

Luna Park

A couples carnival of unlimited rides, fairy floss, souvenir photo and sparkling wine on arrival to celebrate Valentine's Day. Lower Esplanade, St Kilda. $60. 7pm-9.30pm.

WED

Four Tet

Folktronica poster boy Four Tet (real name Kieran Hebden) got awards show props from Radiohead and has collaborated with Burial. Hi Fi Bar, 125 Swantson St, City. $49. 7pm.

THURS

Lamb

Wow -- trip hop happened so long ago. Lamb, from Manchester, released their self-titled debut album, a trip hop opus, in 1996. Prince Bandroom, 29 Fitzroy St, St Kilda. $60+bf. 8pm.

FRI

Derrick Carter

Chicago house DJ Derrick Carter plays in the intimate surrounds of Pretty Please in St Kilda. The besta will be real cozy in there. 61C Fitzroy St, St Kilda. $38.40. 9pm.

TOUR-ISM

LEFTFIELD

Field day

BRITISH electronica act Leftfield has announced a show at the Palace Theatre on March 18. It will feature vocalists Djum Djum, Earl 16 and Cheshire Cat who performed on Leftfield's monumental album, Leftism.

``The opportunity to perform the songs to a whole new audience with the original vocalists is an opportunity that I simply couldn't turn down,'' said Leftfield's Neil Barnes.

Tickets go on sale through Ticketmaster on Thursday.

BLUES FESTIVAL

More names to the list

Byron Bay Blues and Roots Festival has announced more stars to a line-up that already includes Bob Dylan, Elvis Costello and B.B. King. Singer-songwriter Leon Russell, funk master George Clinton and reggae great Ernest Ranglin will join the bill. It is the first Australian visit for Russell, whose songs include A Song for You (covered by Ray Charles), Superstar (The Carpenters) and This Masquerade (George Benson).

Peiris.The new laws, to enter the statute books by August, will replace legislation that is more than 100 years old.Fire control ATHENS - A huge forest fire which had raged through the outskirts of Athens for the past three days, destroying homes and woodland, had been brought largely under control, the fire brigade said today.As gales eased, Greek, French and Italian planes bombarded the blaze with tonnes of water. Five helicopters from Germany were due to join the fight later in the day after the government asked for urgent help from European Union partners.END OF urn:contentItem:5BDG-NXB1-JD34-V4R8-00000-00Top 10 Films2014-02-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisLIFE & STYLEThe Good LifePg. 4Top 10 FilmsSelected by Jake Wilson

1 MODERN TIMES

(97 minutes) G

Charlie Chaplin's 1936 farewell to the silent era is a masterpiece that justifies its title. In his final appearance, Chaplin's Tramp grapples hopelessly with factory machinery and with the larger machine that is society - but still manages to find love (Pauline Goddard, unforgettable). If you've never got the point about Chaplin, here's where to start. Live score by The Sounds of Silent. Digitally projected. George Revival, tomorrow, 4pm. Screens with Chaplin short Making A Living.

2 MY NEIGHBOUR TOTORO

(86 minutes) G

While their mother is in hospital, two little girls distract themselves by exploring the countryside around their new home and finding some magical friends. Like any genuine children's classic, Hayao Miyazaki's beautifully simple 1988 animated fantasy speaks to viewers of every age. ACMI, today, 1pm, tomorrow, 10.30am, 1pm (English-language version, 35-millimetre print) and 1.15pm (Japanese-language version, digitally projected).

3 GIGI

(110 minutes) G

Vincente Minnelli's exquisite visual sense elevates this arch 1958 musical about an innocent Parisian girl (Leslie Caron) groomed for illicit love by her grandmother (Hermoine Gingold). The Oscar-winning sets and costumes are by Cecil Beaton, and Maurice Chevalier leers his way through Thank Heaven For Little Girls. Digitally projected. Astor, tomorrow, 2pm

4 THE PARTY

(99 minutes) G

Blake Edwards was at his peak when he directed this 1967 slapstick classic. Peter Sellers is close to his best as a hapless Indian actor invited to a swinging Hollywood party where he proceeds to destroy everything in sight. Sadly, this screening marks the end for the George Revival, after an adventurous six months. Digitally projected. George Revival, tomorrow, 6.30pm. Free (register for tickets online).

5 A TOUCH OF SIN

(133 minutes) MA

Chinese art filmmaker Jia Zhangke trades his usual contemplative style for something more kinetic in this quartet of short stories on themes of rage and despair. Essential viewing, especially for anyone concerned with the issue of violence in cinema. (See review page 21.) Digitally projected. ACMI, today, 6.30pm, tomorrow, 5.30pm.

6 ALL ABOUT EVE

(138 minutes) PG

Artifice is all in Joseph L. Mankiewicz's campy, brittle, highly enjoyable 1950 tribute to actors and acting, with Bette Davis as an ageing theatre diva, Anne Baxter as her younger rival and George Sanders as a cynical critic (is there any other kind?). 35-millimetre print. Astor, tomorrow, 7pm. Double feature with Lifeboat.

7 WITHNAIL AND I

(108 minutes) M

Bruce Robinson's 1987 comedy gave Richard E. Grant the role of his career as a drunken, unemployed actor who leads his best chum (Paul McGann) into all manner of scrapes; Richard Griffiths is memorable as the lecherous Uncle Monty. Full of brilliant, quotable dialogue, this is a celebration of language as much as anything else. Digitally projected. George Revival, today, 8pm.

8 ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST

(133 minutes) M

Milos Forman's 1975 adaptation of Ken Kesey's novel remains one of the most powerful Hollywood melodramas of its era, however hysterical its sexual politics look today. Jack Nicholson is iconic as a rebellious mental patient, but the linchpin is Louise Fletcher's Nurse Ratched, who's both a sadistic tyrant and a woman isolated in a man's world. Digitally projected. Astor, today, 2pm, 5pm and 8pm.

9 THE DARK KNIGHT

(152 minutes) M

The second of Christopher Nolan's Batman films is by common consent the best, thanks to Heath Ledger's brilliantly alarming turn as the Joker, a psychotic clown who sets out to undermine the moral authority of the impassive hero (Christian Bale). This took the superhero genre to a new level of pop-operatic grandeur. 70-millimetre IMAX print. IMAX Theatre (Melbourne Museum), today, 6pm. Screens as part of a presentation of the Dark Knight Trilogy starting 3pm. Special prices apply.

10 PRINCE AVALANCHE

(94 minutes) M

The unpredictable David Gordon Green (Pineapple Express) is back on form with his latest buddy comedy, featuring Paul Rudd and Emile Hirsch as ill-matched road painters working in rural Texas after a forest fire. It's a virtual two-hander - the third character is the landscape. Digitally projected. Rooftop Cinema (Curtin House), today, 9.30pm.

"I'm not a monster.

I'm just ahead of the curve."

- Morality is for squares according to the Joker (Heath Ledger) in The Dark Knight.

urn:contentItem:4587-DW10-0197-F410-00000-00<published>1999-02-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>HEADSTART; Pg. 2</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ESCAPE TO KALIMANTAN - NOTHING TO REMEMBER</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>TOVEY D / MALONEY S</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ESCAPE TO KALIMANTAN, by Steve Tolbert (Addison, Wesley, Longman, $10.95). Reviewed by Dylan Tovey.</p><p nitf:lede="true">IT'S an unfortunate trend that in recent years books aimed at the young adult audience have been largely peopled with characters from your local soap opera; brimming vessels of teenage angst and lust just waiting to explode with "realistic problems".</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Escape to Kalimantan is a refreshing antidote to these novels. It provides a traditionally plotted adventure story which highlights more important values in today's changing world than what to do when you break up with your boyfriend. At its centre is an examination of conservation issues, including the poaching and trapping of endangered animals in supposedly "protected" areas.</p><p>With a mild "parentally acceptable" adolescent romance, a raging forest fire, and a frantic chase through the undergrowth of the jungle, Escape to Kalimantan will prove just as suitable for parents as for their more socially with-it children.</p><p>NOTHING TO REMEMBER, by Julia Holland (UQP, $13.95). Reviewed by Siobhan Maloney</p><p>LARA Kennedy, aged 15, is struggling to remember her life before the car crash that killed her parents and left her with no memory. Living with her Aunt Vee in a small house on the Gold Coast, Lara spends her days learning how to be normal again. With help from her friend Sudarshan and her brother Rajiv, Lara begins to discover her past and uncover the lies surrounding her life.</p><p>Nothing to Remember is thought-provoking and gentle, with a brief look at Indian culture. Although the ending is a bit unrealistic, Lara is portrayed as an intelligent girl who gradually learns the value of memories and friendship. A great read for ages 11 and over.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier CHART OF THE WEEK

If there's one guaranteed way to spark a 'forest fire' in social media it's to place a photogenic boy band in the middle of Sydney and have them take their shirts off. One Direction, the latest fad in pop music, blew the needle off the chart last week, with almost 12 million social media mentions since April 1, and that's no April Fool's joke. By comparison, the fiasco surrounding the Health Services Union and its maze of connections leading all the way to the PM's office rates just a fraction of the mentions surrounding the British boys.

urn:contentItem:44DX-SCJ0-015G-T4DS-00000-00<published>2001-08-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 32</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Drug lab link to crash</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>DARRELL GILES in Los Angeles</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A MAN has been charged with murdering two fire-fighting pilots after an illegal drug laboratory caught alight, sparking a forest blaze.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The charges came after two fire-fighting planes collided over the bushfire on Monday night.</p><p>Frank Brady, 50, of Redwood Valley, North California, was being held without bail after being charged with two counts of murder.</p><p> He was also charged with attempted manufacture of methamphetamine.</p><p> A second man, Richard Mortensen, 43, of San Pablo, was arrested on outstanding warrants for drug and weapons charges. Mendocino County prosecutor Norm Vroman said Mr Mortensen may also be charged over the tanker pilots' deaths.</p><p> He said the remains of an illegal methamphetamine production laboratory were discovered near where the fire began.</p><p> Mr Brady was caught after a resident reported a black sport utility leaving the scene of the fire. Later that evening, officers arrested Mr Mortensen at Mr Brady's home.</p><p> The two air tankers collided near Hopland, about 160km north of San Francisco, while dumping fire retardant on the 100ha wildfire.</p><p> The pilots were retired navy veteran Larry Groff, 55, and Lars Stratte, 45. They were flying Korean War-era Grumman S-2 planes when they clipped each other during a pass over the blaze.</p><p> The forest fire was one of many raging in</p><p>the west yesterday. In California, a 700ha fire was nearly contained in the hills north of Los Angeles.</p><p> Arsonists were believed responsible for the blaze, which destroyed several homes.</p><p> More than 600 firefighters battled flames fanned by hot wind.</p><p> In Montana, officials at Glacier National Park closed four campgrounds and banned trips into the forest as firefighters battled a 2000ha blaze that burned just west of the park and forced the evacuation of a dozen homes.</p><p> Fires also burned across parts of Idaho, Nevada, Washington and Wyoming.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Pg. 16</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Malaysia chokes out call for help</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MALAYSIANS yesterday prayed for rain and a quick end to the country's worst pollution crisis in eight years as residents choked on acrid forest-fire smoke blowing in from Indonesia.</p><p nitf:lede="true">As the call to prayers echoed from mosques around this mainly Muslim country, Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi called for Muslims, Christians, Buddhists and Hindus to beg divine intervention to wash the skies of a week-long haze that has threatened public health.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"When something like this happens, we have to ask for God's help," Abdullah was quoted as saying in Malay-language newspaper Utusan Malaysia.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Reuters</p></bodyText></section><p>There were early signs yesterday of an easing in the haze, which has sent asthma attacks soaring, forced schools to close, grounded some flights and disrupted shipping.</p><p>But a weather forecaster cautioned that the haze might merely have shifted.</p><p>In Port Klang, Malaysia's biggest port and one of two areas declared an emergency zone yesterday, the sun still appeared as a feeble orange disc through the smog but visibility had improved markedly, a slight breeze blew and fewer people wore face masks.</p><p>Northwest of Kuala Lumpur in Kuala Selangor, the second area put on an emergency footing yesterday, the smog still appeared thick but not as bad as on Thursday, when air-pollution readings soared well into the hazardous zone.</p><p>Sore throats and red eyes are commonplace and face masks are Kuala Lumpur's hottest seller.</p><p>The haze has also threatened the country's tourism industry at an important time when big-spending Middle East visitors flock to country.</p><p>In Sumatra, a short</p><p> ferry ride away from peninsular Malaysia, fires still raged, some of them deep in thick forests which would take more than a day to reach without the aid of helicopters, said a local police chief at Rokan Hilir, where fires have been burning through swampy, remote country.</p><p>Malaysia plans to send 100 firefighters to Sumatra to help the Indonesians douse the flames.</p><p>Air-pollution readings in Malaysia have yet to match the dangerous levels of 1997 when mainly Indonesian fires blotted out skies across South-East Asia, badly hurting tourism.</p><p>Singapore and even parts of Malaysia have been spared this time.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:51T9-5DC1-F0JP-W4TB-00000-00Amid the tensions, messages of conciliation2010-12-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 8Amid the tensions, messages of conciliationABRAHAM RABINOVICH, JERUSALEM

WHILE Israeli troops and Palestinian militants traded threats over the Gaza border, surprising messages of conciliation issued from the Middle East over the Christmas weekend.

The new head of Israel's Mossad spy agency reportedly apologised to British officials for the use of cloned passports in the assassination of a Hamas member in Dubai in January.

Despite escalating tensions with Israel, the dominant Hamas political figure in the Gaza Strip, Mahmoud Zahar, said Hamas wanted to maintain calm with Israel, saying this was ``not a sign of weakness, but strength''.

And Turkish Foreign Minister Ahmed Davutoglu, who has criticised Israel since its forces killed nine Turkish militants trying to break Israel's blockade of Gaza in May, said: ``We have the intention of making peace with Israel.''

Tamir Pardo, who took over command of Mossad this month, was reported by Britain's Daily Telegraph to be planning to meet his British counterparts in MI5 and MI6 when he visits London next month. As well as apologising over the faked passports -- 12 of the 26 used were British -- Mr Pardo will reportedly promise that Israel will never do it again.

The Mossad station chief in London was expelled after then British foreign secretary David Milliband said Israel had shown a ``profound disregard'' for British sovereignty by faking the passports. The aim of Mr Pardo's visit will be to rebuild relations.

In Gaza, Mr Zahar's moderate statement followed the firing of dozens of rockets and mortar shells into Israel, to which Israel responded with airstrikes that killed at least five militants.

A discordant note was struck by the head of Hamas's military wing, Ahmed Ja'abari, who said that in the end Israel would face two choices: ``Death or getting out of Palestinian lands.''

Members of Gaza's small Christian community were permitted to pass through Israeli territory to attend Christmas services in Bethlehem on the West Bank. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas, who met them, told reporters that when a Palestinian state is established ``it would have no Israeli presence in it''. He was referring to Israel's demand that its troops continue to be deployed in the Jordan Valley after the creation of a Palestinian state.

In Turkey, the ferry that was attacked by Israel got a rapturous welcome from thousands yesterday as it returned to Istanbul. Crowds waving Turkish and Palestinian flags lined the quay, chanting ``Allah is Great''.

The Mavi Marmara will be part of a new flotilla that will leave for Gaza on May 31, the anniversary of the raid, its owner said.

Mr Davutoglu, while declaring Ankara's intention to pursue peaceful relations, could not withhold a jab at Israel. Repeating Turkey's demands for an apology for the nine flotilla deaths and compensation for the families, he noted Turkey's swift dispatch of fire-fighting aircraft to help quell a forest fire in Israel this month.

If the situation were reversed, he said, it would have taken Israel days to act. Israel's Foreign Minister, Avigdor Lieberman, gave an angry response. Terming Mr Davutoglu's remarks ``lies'' and ``beyond chutzpah'', he said that if there was an apology to be made it should come from Turkey.

urn:contentItem:7VGX-D3K1-2RG7-250D-00000-00Swift bushfires 'could not be fought'2009-04-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisSwift bushfires 'could not be fought'News Online's Callista Cooper

The counsel assisting the Victorian Bushfires Royal Commission, Jack Rush QC, says while people knew February 7 would be a day of risk, they were not aware they would be dealing with a fire of "phenomenal" speed.

The Black Saturday bushfires ripped across the state in February, claiming 173 lives, devastating 78 communities and destroying 2,029 homes.

Mr Rush told the directions hearing in the Victorian County Court that the commission will hear evidence in the coming weeks that for many people, the warnings were not a trigger to leave their homes early.

"Whilst people knew that the 7th of February would be a day of extreme risk, they did not have the understanding that the risk, as the McArthur Forest Fire Index demonstrated, carried with it the potential of a fire that could not be fought," he said.

"Evidence to be placed before the Royal Commission will indicate that the system of communication of warnings did not cope on 7th February 2009 and that warnings fell behind the advancing fires."

He said bushfire warnings issued will be a particular focus of the first batch of evidence that will be called by the Royal Commission.

"Evidence will demonstrate people remained in their homes unaware of approaching fires, until it was too late," he said.

The stay or go policy will also be a key focus of the Royal Commission.

He said evidence will be heard that Australia's bushfire policy is unique to other countries, with fire authorities giving the public a choice to evacuate or stay and defend their homes.

"There will be evidence to suggest that accurate or timely information was not available during 7 February 2009," he said.

"Why would a resident of any of the fire affected areas implement the go policy if they were not aware of any fire threat?"

Mr Rush has told the commission there is no national standard for bushfire warnings and he says it is unclear who has responsibility for issuing warnings in Victoria.

The commission will also tackle the issue of fire refuges.

Mr Rush said fire refuges were recommended in the Ash Wednesday fire report, however over time refuges have been decommissioned.

He said there is a level of uncertainty in the community regarding fire refuges and evidence may permit the royal commission to make findings regarding this.

Mr Rush said the issue of prescribed burning will also be addressed, with a range of strongly held views to be heard in relation to this contentious subject.

Witnesses will begin giving evidence on May 11.

Commissioner Bernard Teague told the court the Royal Commission's terms of reference are extremely wide and they will focus on how to limit the devastation of any future bushfire "and specifically on how to save human lives".

The commission is due to deliver an interim report in August.

urn:contentItem:51M5-N5T1-F0JP-W2MG-00000-00Sevendays2010-12-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 52SevendaysGraham Clark

FRIDAY

AUSTRALIA'S $46 million bid headed by shopping centre magnate Frank Lowy (pictured) to host the 2022 soccer World Cup ended as Qatar emerged the victors while Russia won the rights to host the 2018 contest.

RUSSIAN President Dmitry Medvedev performed chin-ups on TV, flexing his muscles as he battles perceptions presidential successor Vladimir Putin is the real strongman of Moscow.

MORE than 40 people were killed, including many prison guards, in a forest fire in Israel.

THURSDAY

VENEZUELAN President Hugo Chavez (pictured) said he had given shelter at his palace to 26 families left homeless by recent heavy rains.

A NEW Zealand truck driver caught smoking cannabis while driving a 40-tonne dangerous goods truck told police he took the drug to ease constipation, but insisted he had had only two bongs and kept his hands on the wheel at all times.

HEAVY snow continued to wreak havoc in Europe, killing 26 in Poland, the Czech Republic, Lithuania and Britain.

WEDNESDAY

DESPITE controversial WikiLeaks claims, Pakistan dismissed reports that London and Washington feared its nuclear weapons could fall into the hands of terrorists in the strife-hit country. Answering another WikiLeak, Bolivian officials denied a claim President Evo Morales (pictured) had a tumour in his nose.

A PENTAGON report found that ending a ban on gay soldiers serving openly would create no serious problems for the US military as the White House pressed for repealing the law.

TUESDAY

FRENCH electrician Pierre Le Guennec (pictured) denied claims he had stolen 271 Pablo Picasso artworks which he revealed had sat in his garage for 30 years, saying the artist's second wife had given them to him when he was working on their house.

AN Afghani in police uniform shot dead six US troops during a training session in the east of the country.

CHRISTIE'S sold a 14.2-carat diamond dubbed The Perfect Pink for $23.9 million at auction in Hong Kong.

MONDAY

AFTER 11 years of Labor rule and days of uncertainty Victorian premier John Brumby (pictured) conceded the Coalition led by Liberal Ted Baillieu had won the cliffhanger state election.

A MACAU casino tycoon paid $342,950 for two white truffles, one weighing 900g from Italy's central Tuscany region and the other 400g at a charity auction.

IRAN accused Israel and the West of orchestrating the killing of a nuclear scientist and the wounding of another in Tehran.

SUNDAY

BRITAIN and much of Europe faced bitter winter weather with icy winds and driving snow across the northeast blanketing much of England, Wales and Scotland and forcing the cancellation of hundreds of flights.

SOMALIA-BORN Mohamed Osman Mohamud, 19, was charged by the FBI with attempting to bomb a Christmas tree-lighting ceremony in the US state of Oregon.

TEN people died after a cargo plane with an engine on fire crashed into a residential area of Karachi in Pakistan.

SATURDAY

AFTER 70 years Russia acknowledged dictator Joseph Stalin (pictured) ordered the World War II massacre of thousands of Polish officers.

DAYS after North Korea shelled a South Korean island killing four people, the North's leader, Kim Jong-Il, warned his country was close to war as US and South Korean naval forces prepared for joint exercises.

BERNARD Matthews, who raised turkeys in spare rooms in his country house then became Britain's largest turkey processor, died aged 80.

urn:contentItem:5JT0-WHP1-DY19-C3WK-00000-00When should we worry about climate change?2016-05-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:49ZLexisNexisWhen should we worry about climate change?Peter Hannam, Environment editor

News that Tasmania's Cape Grim weather site had recorded its first baseline reading of 400 parts per million of carbon dioxide sparked some debate over the meaning of the milestone.

As we noted ahead of the declaration of the first recording of 400ppm in the southern hemisphere, the primary greenhouse gas increase carried not much more global warming significance than, say, 399 or 401 ppm.

"People react to these things when they see thresholds crossed," David Etheridge, a CSIRO principal research scientist, told us, perhaps a little optimistically.

Even more upbeat was Paul Fraser, the CSIRO scientist who had helped set up Cape Grim 40 years ago. He told 9news.com.au that passing the landmark would be a "psychological tipping point".

Other warning signs - such as the 1 degree warming point reached last year - did at least spur nations to agree at the Paris Climate Summit that temperature increases should be limited to 1.5-2 degrees, even if national policies made 3 degrees more likely.

And so, with CO2 concentrations marching past 400 ppm, when should we start worrying about global warming?

Does 400 ppm means we should start worrying now or when should we have started?

"About 30 years ago," is the blunt answer from David Karoly, a climate scientist with Melbourne University.

"But we shouldn't give up, either," he told me this week. "The worry - and the [climate] action - should now be increased."

Worries mount

There's certainly a lot to be concerned about in 2016.

Each of the last 12 months is now the hottest on record for that month, with April adding the recent string of beating-by-biggest-margin months.

(See NASA's chart showing temperatures were 1.11 degrees warmer than the 1951-80 average, with large areas in the north particularly warm, while Australia had its second-warmest April.)

Among the climate-related threats, Canada's forest fire season started about a month early. One huge blaze near Alberta's tar sands forced the evacuation of about 88,000 people from the city of Fort McMurray.

The monster El Nino, riding on top of about one degree of background warming, has triggered widespread bleaching of the corals around the world, including our cherished - but apparently expendable - Great Barrier Reef.

More than half the corals in the largely pristine northern end are now dying or dead the reef's Marine Park Authority chief Russell Reichelt told the Senate earlier this month.

On the plus side

However, a dose of of warming can be welcomed where it take off the chill - as in parts of the US - or in Sydney,   where summer feels like never lost of its grip even with winter just weeks away.

And all that extra CO2 is leading to a "greening" of the planet with about one-quarter of humans' carbon emissions being taken up by plants, a recent Nature paper found.

But many other changes are far from benign - at least according to the preservation of many existing eco-systems.

Less glamorous than corals, the kelp forests off eastern Tasmania are being destroyed by warm water species swept south by the strengthening and warming East Australian Current. Similarly, the massive dieback of mangrove forest in the Gulf of Carpentaria apparently linked to extreme weather got scant national media coverage.

And, as for the high Arctic and the remarkably prolonged above-average temperatures, changes up there are likely to be further from our daily consciousness.

Anomalously low #Arctic sea ice extent continues with the 48th consecutive day of a new daily record minimum value   pic.twitter.com/aVfFwAZx0J

??? Zack Labe (@ZLabe) May 16, 2016

But less sea ice means less light reflected back to space and more heat absorbed by the oceans - and so the cycle builds and so should our concern.

Spiral warning

In case you missed it, Ed Hawkins, a climate scientist at the UK's University of Reading, came up with the illustration below to help us appreciate the spiralling warming trend since the middle of the 19th century.

By that gauge, when the temperature increase breaks past the 1.5 degrees warming - perhaps in coming months before the El Nino in the Pacific fully stops giving back heat to the atmosphere - will be sufficiently concerned then to act?

Climate scientists, such as Professor Karoly, know globally warming limits agreed at international summits to prevent dangerous climate change - such as 1.5-2 degrees range agreed in Paris - are arbitrary in a similar way to 400 ppm.

"You'd be hard-pressed to find scientists agreeing that 1.5 degrees would be manageable for our reef," he said. "Look at what's happening to the reef this year - and that's with 1 degree warming."

Recent work by his team has identified that on current temperature and carbon emissions trends, the Great Barrier Reef will be hit by bleaching events every second year by 2035.

Other eco-systems, such as alpine ones, are also being affected as species helped by cool temperatures have literally nowhere to hide.

Big one to worry about

Natural fluctuations mean temperature spikes such as we have seen over the past year can recede - at least partly.

As this year's El Nino in the Pacific lurches towards becoming a La Nina - when equatorial winds turn back to be mostly west-ward blowing and strengthen - expect the run of record temperature reading to be broken.

With rising greenhouse gas concentrations, the heat we are trapping in the Earth's biosphere - the lands, air and seas - will keep on increasing.

And for those climate sceptics who thought the first decade of the 21st century marked a slowdown in temperature increases - the so-called "warming hiatus" - their case for holding off carbon emission cuts is about to get harder to make.

As Fairfax Media noted back in late 2014, a long-lived climate phenomenon named the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, has begun to switch to its positive phase. In fact, climate experts have in the past few days detected   it hitting a new high.

Such a PDO switch - it is an 11-year rolling average - would indicate oceans will become less of a sink for the planet's surplus heat - and may even give more of it back.

That means global conditions will favour more El Nino events but also when La Ninas come, they will tend to be more extreme.

For Australia that could mean more severe tropical cyclones, although parched inland regions may get some rainfall relief.

A PDO switch, however, would likely see an acceleration in global temperature increases, with all the unpleasant outcomes for corals, glacier melting and disappearing Arctic sea ice.

In other words, we could soon have a lot more to worry about.
